paragraph.content: provide for the strict liability of owners of goods vehicles and special purpose vehicles regarding the overloading of their vehicles. (Added 90 of 1993 s. 3)

section.name: s14
section.heading: Onus of proof in certain cases

subsection.leadIn: Any regulation made under this Ordinance may provide that in any criminal proceedings for a contravention thereof—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: it shall be for the person accused of such contravention to prove certain facts; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: facts shall be presumed, with or without proof of other facts, until the contrary is proved.

subsection.content: Any regulation made in exercise of the powers conferred by subsection (1) shall be subject to the approval of the Legislative Council.

section.name: s14A
section.heading: Transitional provisions in regulations
section.leadIn: Any regulation made under this Ordinance may—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: provide for the continuance in force of any regulations made under the repealed Ordinance with such modifications, adaptations and transitional provisions as the Chief Executive in Council sees fit; and (Amended 3 of 2002 s. 15)

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: provide for the modification, adaptation and transition of any reference in any Ordinance to the repealed Ordinance or any regulations made under the repealed Ordinance.

section.name: s15
section.heading: Penalties under the regulations
section.content: Any regulation made under section 6, 6A, 7, 7A, 8, 9, 10, 11, 12, 12A, 121 or 131 may provide that a contravention thereof shall be an offence, and may provide penalties for such offence not exceeding a fine at level 4 and imprisonment for 12 months.

subsection.content: There shall be a panel from which members of Transport Tribunals may be appointed under this Ordinance. (Amended 89 of 1994 s. 12)
The panel shall consist of such persons, not being public officers, as the Secretary may appoint. (Amended L.N. 362 of 1997; 19 of 2004 s. 3; L.N. 130 of 2007; 6 of 2012 s. 2)
The appointment of any person as a member of the panel shall have effect for not more than 3 years and a member of the panel shall be eligible for reappointment.
A member of the panel may resign at any time by notice in writing to the Secretary. (Amended L.N. 362 of 1997; 19 of 2004 s. 3; L.N. 130 of 2007; 6 of 2012 s. 2)
The Secretary may appoint such Transport Tribunals as may from time to time be necessary for the purposes of this Ordinance.

subsection.leadIn: A Transport Tribunal shall consist of—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a chairman, who shall be a person other than a public officer, appointed by the Secretary; and (Amended 89 of 1994 s. 13)

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: 2 members of the panel appointed under section 16. (Replaced 89 of 1994 s. 13)

subsection.content: A Transport Tribunal shall have a legal adviser who may be present at any hearing of the Tribunal in order to advise the Tribunal on any matter. (Amended 89 of 1994 s. 14)
A Transport Tribunal may, in connection with any hearing before it, consult a legal adviser on any question of law, procedure or any other matter.
The Chairman of a Transport Tribunal may by notice in writing summon any person to appear before the Tribunal to produce any document or to give evidence.

A Transport Tribunal may receive such evidence as it thinks fit, and neither the provisions of the Evidence Ordinance (Cap. 8) nor any other rule of law relating to the admissibility of evidence shall apply in the proceedings before the Tribunal.

Any question arising in proceedings before a Transport Tribunal, not being a question relating to the practice and procedure of the Tribunal, shall, in the event of a difference between the members, be decided by the majority.

content.leadIn: Any person, who being summoned to appear before a Transport Tribunal, refuses or fails without reasonable excuse to appear or to answer any question put to him by or with the consent of the Tribunal commits an offence and is liable to a fine at level 1 and to imprisonment for 3 months: (Amended E.R. 2 of 2021)
content.proviso: Provided that no person shall be bound to incriminate himself and every witness shall, in respect of any evidence given by him before the Tribunal, be entitled to the privileges to which he would be entitled if giving evidence before a court.

subsection.content: Any person who behaves in an insulting manner or uses any threatening or insulting expression to or in the presence of a Transport Tribunal commits an offence and is liable to a fine at level 1 and to imprisonment for 3 months. (Amended E.R. 2 of 2021)

section.name: s20
section.heading: Practice and procedure of Transport Tribunal

subsection.content: Save in so far as provision is made therefor in this Ordinance, the practice and procedure in and in connection with any hearing before a Transport Tribunal shall be such as the Chairman of the Tribunal may determine.
In proceedings before a Transport Tribunal, any person may appear in person or be represented by counsel, solicitor or agent.
For the purposes of registration and licensing of vehicles under this Ordinance, vehicles are classified in accordance with Schedule 1.
The Secretary may by order amend Schedule 1. (Amended 89 of 1994 s. 15; L.N. 106 of 2002; L.N. 130 of 2007; 6 of 2012 s. 2)
Except as otherwise provided by this Ordinance, every vehicle of a class specified in Schedule 1 which is used on any road shall be licensed.

subsection.leadIn: A vehicle, other than a rickshaw, shall not be licensed under this Ordinance—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: unless it is registered; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: other than in the class within which it is registered.

subsection.content: Subject to sections 23, 24 and 26, the Commissioner shall register a vehicle in accordance with this Ordinance on application made in the prescribed manner.
Subject to sections 25 and 26, the Commissioner shall license a registered vehicle or a rickshaw in accordance with this Ordinance on application made in the prescribed manner.

section.name: s23
section.heading: Power to regulate the number of vehicles registered

subsection.leadIn: Without prejudice to any other enactment, the Chief Executive in Council by notice in the Gazette may limit the number of vehicles which may at any time be registered by reference to any one or more of the following— (Amended 3 of 2002 s. 15)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the total number of vehicles in all classes;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a class or description of vehicle or a description of the conditions subject to which vehicle licences will be issued;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the date of manufacture of vehicles;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: the country of origin of vehicles.

subsection.content: Subject to subsection (3), any limit notified under subsection (1) shall remain in force for such period not exceeding 12 months as shall be specified in the notice.
The Legislative Council may from time to time by resolution extend the period for which a limit remains in force under subsection (2).
Any limit notified under subsection (1) shall not affect the registration of any vehicle in force when the notice comes into operation.

subsection.leadIn: If the Commissioner—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: receives applications for the registration of vehicles within a category of vehicle which is the subject of a notice under subsection (1); and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: would, but for the limit under subsection (1) on the number of vehicles that may be registered in that category, grant the applications,

subsection.continued: the Commissioner may cause the applications to be determined by lot.

subsection.leadIn: The Commissioner may refuse to register any motor vehicle—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: which does not accord with the particulars contained in the application for the registration thereof;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: which has been but is no longer registered in Hong Kong;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: which is not roadworthy;

paragraph.name: ca
paragraph.content: which does not comply with vehicle design standards; (Amended 3 of 1991 s. 3)

paragraph.name: cb
paragraph.leadIn: which—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: is the subject of first registration; and

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: does not comply with noise emission standards; (Added 13 of 1996 s. 3)

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: in order to comply with a limit which is in force under section 23; or

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.leadIn: in respect of which—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: a notice under section 78 has not been complied with; or

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: a fee payable under section 86 has not been paid.

subsection.content: The Commissioner may refuse to register a motor vehicle in the class specified in the application for its registration if he considers that by reason of its design or construction or otherwise the vehicle is not suitable for registration in that class.
The Commissioner may refuse to register any vehicle which is already registered.

section.name: s25
section.heading: Power to refuse or cancel licence and to impose conditions in respect of taxis

subsection.leadIn: The Commissioner may—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: refuse to license; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: cancel the licence of,

subsection.continued: a motor vehicle if—

paragraph.name: i
ia
paragraph.content: by reason of its design or construction, or any adaptation or the condition thereof, the vehicle or any equipment thereof does not comply with vehicle design standards; (Added 3 of 1991 s. 4)

paragraph.name: ib
paragraph.content: the registered owner of the vehicle fails to have the vehicle tested at a vehicle emission testing centre (within the meaning of Part 8A) when required to do so by the Commissioner under section 77B; (Added 3 of 1991 s. 4)

paragraph.name: ic
paragraph.content: the Commissioner has reasonable grounds to believe that its vehicle identification number has been altered or tampered with; (Added 89 of 1994 s. 16)

paragraph.name: ii
iia
paragraph.content: the registered owner of the vehicle fails to have the vehicle examined at a car testing centre (within the meaning of Part 9A) when required to do so by the Commissioner under section 88B(1); (Added 3 of 1991 s. 4)

paragraph.name: iib
paragraph.content: on examination under Part 8A the vehicle is found not to comply with vehicle emission standards; (Added 3 of 1991 s. 4)

paragraph.name: iic
paragraph.content: the vehicle or any equipment thereof does not comply with any requirement imposed by regulations made under section 43(1) of the Air Pollution Control Ordinance (Cap. 311) in relation to the prohibition or control of the emission of air pollutants from motor vehicles; (Added 3 of 1991 s. 4)

paragraph.name: iii
paragraph.content: on examination under Part 9 or 9A the vehicle is found to be not roadworthy; (Amended 65 of 1985 s. 2)

paragraph.name: iv
paragraph.content: any of the particulars contained in the application for the licence do not accord with the particulars contained in the register;

paragraph.name: v
paragraph.content: the vehicle does not accord with the particulars contained in the application for the licence;

paragraph.name: vi
paragraph.content: no valid insurance in respect of third party risks as required by the Motor Vehicles Insurance (Third Party Risks) Ordinance (Cap. 272) is in force in respect of the vehicle; or

paragraph.name: vii
paragraph.content: in the case of a private bus, school private light bus, public light bus or public bus (other than a bus operated under a franchise granted under the Public Bus Services Ordinance (Cap. 230)) no passenger service licence is in force in respect of the vehicle. (Amended 50 of 1999 s. 8)

subsection.leadIn: The Commissioner may—

paragraph.name: a
b
paragraph.content: license a motor vehicle as a taxi subject to such conditions as he may specify.

subsection.leadIn: Conditions which the Commissioner may specify under subsection (2)(b) shall include conditions as to—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: an area outside which the vehicle shall not be available for hire or to carry passengers;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the place on any road at which passengers may board or alight from the vehicle;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: parking of the vehicle in particular places at particular time;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: standards of cleanliness of the vehicle;

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: the colour of the vehicle;

paragraph.name: f
paragraph.content: markings and signs to be exhibited on the vehicle; (Amended 67 of 1994 s. 2)

paragraph.name: g
paragraph.content: the form of advertising signs in or on the vehicle; and (Amended 67 of 1994 s. 2)

paragraph.name: h
paragraph.content: the period, after the licence is issued, within which the ownership of the vehicle shall not be transferred. (Added 67 of 1994 s. 2)

subsection.name: 3A
subsection.content: If there is any inconsistency between a condition specified by the Commissioner under subsection (2)(b) and a condition of a taxi fleet licence issued under a regulation made under section 7A, the latter prevails to the extent of the inconsistency. (Added 34 of 2023 s. 6)

subsection.leadIn: The Commissioner, on application to license a motor vehicle as a taxi shall take into account, in addition to any other matter which he considers relevant to the application—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the type of vehicle in respect of which application for the licence is made; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: garaging and maintenance facilities available to the applicant.

subsection.leadIn: The Commissioner may, on any reasonable ground—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: refuse to register any trailer;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: refuse to license any trailer or rickshaw; or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: cancel the licence of any trailer or rickshaw.

subsection.leadIn: Without prejudice to subsection (1), the Commissioner may—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: refuse to license; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: cancel the licence of,

subsection.continued: any trailer or rickshaw which in his opinion—

paragraph.name: i
paragraph.content: does not accord with the particulars contained in the application for the licence; or

paragraph.name: ii
paragraph.content: is not roadworthy.

subsection.leadIn: The Commissioner may license a trailer or rickshaw subject to such conditions relating to—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the roads on which it may be used;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the hours when it may be used; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: in the case of a trailer, the type of towing vehicle that may be used to tow it,

subsection.continued: as he thinks fit.

subsection.content: Subject to the provisions of this section and of sections 28 and 29, the Commissioner may, on application made in the prescribed manner, issue a passenger service licence in respect of one or more public buses, public light buses, private buses or school private light buses for use in accordance with this Ordinance. (Amended 50 of 1999 s. 9)
Subsection (1) does not apply to a public bus operated under a franchise granted under the Public Bus Services Ordinance (Cap. 230).

subsection.leadIn: A passenger service licence may authorize the holder to operate—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a public bus service;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a private bus service; (Amended 50 of 1999 s. 9)

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: a public light bus service; or (Amended 50 of 1999 s. 9)

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: a school private light bus service. (Added 50 of 1999 s. 9)

subsection.leadIn: For the purposes of subsection (3)(a) a public bus service means a service which—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: is for the carriage of passengers by public bus; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: is of a type specified in section 4(3) of the Public Bus Services Ordinance (Cap. 230) or of any other type approved by the Commissioner; and (Amended 66 of 1984 s. 4)

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: is not required to be operated under a franchise granted under the Public Bus Services Ordinance (Cap. 230).

subsection.leadIn: For the purposes of subsection (3)(b) a private bus service means—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a student service, that is to say, a service for the carriage to or from an educational institution of students thereof and persons accompanying or in charge of such students or who teach at the educational institution, in private buses registered in the name of the educational institution;

paragraph.name: b
c
paragraph.content: a disabled persons’ service, that is to say, a service provided exclusively for the carriage of disabled persons and of persons employed to assist them; (Amended 66 of 1984 s. 4)

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: any other service, which is not for hire or reward, approved by the Commissioner. (Added 66 of 1984 s. 4)

subsection.content: For the purposes of subsection (3)(c) a public light bus service means a service for the carriage by public light bus of passengers at separate fares.
A passenger service licence shall not be transferable.

section.name: s28
section.heading: Matters to be taken into account in considering an application for a passenger service licence
section.leadIn: In determining an application for a passenger service licence, the Commissioner shall take into account, in addition to any other matter which he considers relevant to the application—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: any policy direction from the Chief Executive with respect to the provision of public transport services; (Amended 3 of 2002 s. 15)

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: any limit in force under section 23 on the number of vehicles that may be registered;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the need for the services to be provided by the applicant;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: the level of service already provided or planned by other public transport operators;

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: traffic conditions in the areas and on the roads where the services are to be provided; and

paragraph.name: f
paragraph.content: the standard of service to be provided by the applicant.

section.name: s29
section.heading: Commissioner’s power to refuse an application for a passenger service licence

subsection.leadIn: The Commissioner may—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: refuse to issue a passenger service licence; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: issue a passenger service licence subject to such conditions as he may specify, which shall include conditions as to—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: the number and types of vehicles that the licensee may use;

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: the purposes for which the vehicles may be used;

subparagraph.name: iii
subparagraph.content: the areas or routes in or on which the vehicles may be used;

subparagraph.name: iv
subparagraph.content: the places at which the vehicles may stand or stop to pick up or set down passengers;

subparagraph.name: v
subparagraph.content: the garage facilities that the licensee must maintain;

subparagraph.name: vi
subparagraph.content: where the Commissioner thinks fit, the staff that the licensee must employ;

subparagraph.name: vii
subparagraph.content: the records that the licensee must keep;

subparagraph.name: viii
subparagraph.content: the fares to be charged; and

subparagraph.name: ix
subparagraph.content: the frequency at which and the period on each day during which the service shall be operated on routes specified in the licence.

subsection.content: Without limiting the generality of subsection (1)(a), the Commissioner may refuse to issue a passenger service licence in respect of any vehicle which is not, or is not to be, owned by the applicant for the licence.

section.name: s30
section.heading: Inquiry where passenger service licence is contravened

subsection.leadIn: If the Commissioner has reason to believe in respect of any vehicle in respect of which a passenger service licence is in force that—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the vehicle has been or is being used otherwise than for the purpose of the service authorized by the licence; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: any condition of the licence or any provision of this Ordinance has not been or is not being complied with,

subsection.continued: he may appoint a public officer to hold an inquiry.

subsection.content: An officer appointed under subsection (1) shall fix a time and place for the inquiry and shall give 21 clear days’ written notice thereof to the licensee.

An inquiry may be postponed if the officer conducting it thinks fit and where an inquiry is postponed the officer shall cause a notice to be served on the licensee specifying the date to which the inquiry has been postponed.

subsection.leadIn: At an inquiry the officer conducting the inquiry shall consider—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: any evidence received by him, whether tendered on behalf of the licensee or otherwise, and any representations made by or on behalf of the licensee or otherwise;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: representations in writing by or on behalf of the licensee.

section.name: s31
section.heading: Commissioner’s power to cancel, suspend or vary a passenger service licence
section.leadIn: If after considering the report of an officer who has conducted an inquiry under section 30 the Commissioner is satisfied as to the matters set out in subsection (1)(a) or (b) of that section he may—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: suspend or cancel the passenger service licence;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: suspend or cancel the passenger service licence in respect of particular vehicles; or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.leadIn: vary the passenger service licence in respect of—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: routes;

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: approved purposes;

subparagraph.name: iii
subparagraph.content: the number of vehicles included in the licence,

section.continued: and shall notify the licensee of his decision.

section.name: s32
section.heading: Effective date of a cancellation, suspension or variation

subsection.content: Subject to subsection (2), a cancellation, suspension or variation under section 31 shall come into effect 21 days from the date of notification to the licensee.

subsection.leadIn: If a licensee applies for a review of the Commissioner’s decision by a Transport Tribunal under section 33, a cancellation, suspension or variation shall not take effect pending the review, and shall take effect—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: where the application for the review is deemed to have been withdrawn under section 34(4); or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: where the cancellation, suspension or variation is confirmed or varied by a Transport Tribunal under section 35(2),

subsection.continued: on such date as the Commissioner shall specify in a notice served on the licensee.

section.name: s33
section.heading: Right of review of Commissioner’s determination under section 24, 25, 26, 29, or 31

subsection.leadIn: Subject to subsection (2), where the Commissioner—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: refuses to register a vehicle under section 24 or 26;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: refuses to license a vehicle or cancels a licence under section 25 or 26;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: refuses to issue a passenger service licence under section 29 or cancels, suspends or varies a passenger service licence under section 31,

subsection.continued: the applicant or the holder of the licence may, within 21 days of being notified of the decision of the Commissioner, apply in writing to the Commissioner for a review of the Commissioner’s decision by a Transport Tribunal.

subsection.leadIn: This section shall not apply where the Commissioner—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: refuses to register a motor vehicle under section 24(1)(d) or (e);

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: refuses to license or cancels a motor vehicle licence under section 25(1)(ii).

subsection.content: On receipt of an application under section 33 the Commissioner shall fix a time and place for the review and shall give 14 clear days’ notice thereof to the applicant.
The Commissioner shall, so far as practicable, ensure that the date of the review is not more than 30 days after the date of service of the notice under subsection (1).

A Transport Tribunal may postpone a review if it thinks fit and where a review is postponed the Commissioner shall cause a notice to be served on the applicant specifying the date to which the review has been postponed.

subsection.leadIn: If an applicant or his authorized representative—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: does not appear before the Transport Tribunal on the date of the review notified to him in a notice under subsection (1) or (3); or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: makes no written representations,

subsection.continued: the application for a review shall be deemed to have been withdrawn.

subsection.leadIn: On a review a Transport Tribunal shall consider—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: any evidence received by it, whether tendered on behalf of the applicant or otherwise, which it considers relevant to the review;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: any representations made by or on behalf of the applicant, whether orally or in writing;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: any representations made by or on behalf of the Commissioner, whether orally or in writing.

subsection.content: The Transport Tribunal may confirm or reverse a decision of the Commissioner under section 24, 25 or 26 and may confirm, reverse or vary a decision of the Commissioner under section 29 or 31.
The Commissioner shall notify an applicant of the Transport Tribunal’s decision under subsection (2).
The decision of the Transport Tribunal under subsection (2) shall be final.

subsection.leadIn: A person who causes the death of another person by driving a motor vehicle on a road dangerously commits an offence and is liable—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: on conviction on indictment to a fine at level 5 and to imprisonment for 10 years; (Amended 23 of 2008 s. 5)

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: on summary conviction to a fine at level 4 and to imprisonment for 2 years.

subsection.content: If a court or magistrate convicts a person of an offence under subsection (1), the court or magistrate shall order that the person be disqualified in accordance with subsection (2A) or (2B) unless the court or magistrate for special reasons orders that the person be disqualified for a shorter period or that the person not be disqualified. (Replaced 23 of 2008 s. 5)

subsection.name: 2A
subsection.leadIn: Subject to subsection (2B), the person is to be disqualified—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: in the case of a first conviction, for a period of not less than 5 years; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: in the case of a second or subsequent conviction, for a period of not less than 10 years. (Added 23 of 2008 s. 5. Amended 19 of 2010 s. 6; 24 of 2011 s. 6)

subsection.name: 2AB
subsection.leadIn: A court or magistrate may, in making an order that a person be disqualified in accordance with subsection (2A), order that the person be disqualified for life, if—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the person has been convicted of the same offence previously; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: having regard to the circumstances in which the offence was committed (which may include but is not limited to those set out in subsection (2E)) and the behaviour of the person, the court or magistrate is of the opinion that it is undesirable for the person to continue to be allowed to drive a motor vehicle. (Added 24 of 2011 s. 6)

subsection.name: 2B
subsection.leadIn: If the court or magistrate has ordered the person to attend and complete a driving improvement course under section 72A(1A), the person is to be disqualified—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: in the case of a first conviction, for a period of not less than 5 years, or until the person has attended and completed the course at his own cost, whichever is the later; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: in the case of a second or subsequent conviction, for a period of not less than 10 years, or until the person has attended and completed the course at his own cost, whichever is the later. (Added 23 of 2008 s. 5. Amended 19 of 2010 s. 6; 24 of 2011 s. 6)

subsection.name: 2C
subsection.leadIn: For the purposes of subsection (2), a person to whom subsection (2B) applies is disqualified for a shorter period if he is disqualified—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: in the case of a first conviction, for a period of less than 5 years, or until the person has attended and completed the driving improvement course at his own cost, whichever is the later; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: in the case of a second or subsequent conviction, for a period of less than 10 years, or until the person has attended and completed the driving improvement course at his own cost, whichever is the later. (Added 23 of 2008 s. 5. Amended 19 of 2010 s. 6; 24 of 2011 s. 6)

subsection.name: 2D
subsection.content: If an offence under subsection (1) is committed in circumstances of aggravation, the maximum fine and term of imprisonment for the offence as set out in subsection (1), and the minimum disqualification periods for the offence as set out in subsections (2A) and (2B), are each increased by 50% and subsection (2C) must be construed accordingly. (Added 19 of 2010 s. 6)

subsection.name: 2E
subsection.leadIn: A person commits an offence under subsection (1) in circumstances of aggravation if at the time of committing the offence—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the proportion of alcohol in the person’s breath, blood or urine is tier 3; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: any concentration of a specified illicit drug is present in the person’s blood or urine. (Added 19 of 2010 s. 6. Amended 24 of 2011 s. 6)

subsection.name: 2F
subsection.content: To avoid doubt and despite anything to the contrary in section 113C of the Criminal Procedure Ordinance (Cap. 221), the maximum fine for an offence under subsection (1) committed in circumstances of aggravation is the monetary amount derived by multiplying by 1.5 the maximum fine for the offence as set out in subsection (1). (Added 19 of 2010 s. 6)

The court or magistrate may deal with the conviction of an offence as a first conviction (including for the purposes of subsection (2AB)(a)) if, as at the date on which the offence was committed, at least 5 years have elapsed since the person’s last conviction under subsection (1). (Replaced 23 of 2008 s. 5. Amended 24 of 2011 s. 6)

subsection.leadIn: A person is to be regarded as driving dangerously within the meaning of subsection (1) if—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the way he drives falls far below what would be expected of a competent and careful driver; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: it would be obvious to a competent and careful driver that driving in that way would be dangerous.

subsection.content: A person is also to be regarded as driving dangerously within the meaning of subsection (1) if it would be obvious to a competent and careful driver that driving the motor vehicle concerned in its current state would be dangerous.
For the purposes of subsections (4) and (5), dangerous refers to danger either of injury to any person or of serious damage to property.

subsection.leadIn: For the purposes of subsections (4) and (5), in determining what would be expected of, or obvious to, a competent and careful driver in a particular case, regard shall be had to all the circumstances of the case including—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the nature, condition and use of the road concerned at the material time;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the amount of traffic which is actually on the road concerned at the material time or which might reasonably be expected to be on the road concerned at the material time; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the circumstances (including the physical condition of the accused) of which the accused could be expected to be aware and any circumstances (including the physical condition of the accused) shown to have been within the knowledge of the accused.

subsection.content: In determining for the purposes of subsection (5) the state of the motor vehicle, regard may be had to anything attached to or carried on or in it and to the manner in which it is attached or carried.

If on the trial of any person charged with an offence under subsection (1) the prosecution proves that the person charged drove dangerously but not that he caused the death of another person by so driving, the person charged shall be acquitted of the offence under subsection (1) and be found guilty of an offence under section 37.

subsection.name: 9A
subsection.content: If on the trial of any person charged with an offence under subsection (1) the prosecution proves that the person charged drove dangerously and caused grievous bodily harm to, but not the death of, another person by so driving, the person charged must be acquitted of the offence under subsection (1) and be found guilty of an offence under section 36A. (Added 19 of 2010 s. 6)

On the trial of any person charged with an offence under subsection (1), the person charged may be acquitted of the offence under subsection (1) and be found guilty of one or more offences under section 38, 39, 39A, 39J, 39K or 39L. (Amended 24 of 2011 s. 6)

section.name: s36A
section.heading: Causing grievous bodily harm by dangerous driving

subsection.leadIn: A person who causes grievous bodily harm to another person by driving a motor vehicle on a road dangerously commits an offence and is liable—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: on conviction on indictment to a fine at level 5 and to imprisonment for 7 years;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: on summary conviction to a fine at level 4 and to imprisonment for 2 years.

subsection.content: If a court or magistrate convicts a person of an offence under subsection (1), the court or magistrate must order that the person be disqualified in accordance with subsection (3) or (4) unless the court or magistrate for special reasons orders that the person be disqualified for a shorter period or that the person not be disqualified.

subsection.leadIn: Subject to subsection (4), the period for which the person is to be disqualified is—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: for a first conviction, a period of not less than 2 years; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: for a second or subsequent conviction, a period of not less than 5 years.

subsection.leadIn: If the court or magistrate has ordered the person to attend and complete a driving improvement course under section 72A(1A), the period for which the person is to be disqualified is—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: for a first conviction, a period of not less than 2 years, or until the person has attended and completed the course at his or her own cost, whichever is the later; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: for a second or subsequent conviction, a period of not less than 5 years, or until the person has attended and completed the course at his or her own cost, whichever is the later.

subsection.leadIn: For the purposes of subsection (2), a person to whom subsection (4) applies is disqualified for a shorter period if the period for which he or she is disqualified is—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: for a first conviction, a period of less than 2 years, or until the person has attended and completed the driving improvement course at his or her own cost, whichever is the later; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: for a second or subsequent conviction, a period of less than 5 years, or until the person has attended and completed the driving improvement course at his or her own cost, whichever is the later.

subsection.content: If an offence under subsection (1) is committed in circumstances of aggravation, the maximum fine and term of imprisonment for the offence as set out in subsection (1), and the minimum disqualification periods for the offence as set out in subsections (3) and (4), are each increased by 50% and subsection (5) must be construed accordingly.

subsection.leadIn: A person commits an offence under subsection (1) in circumstances of aggravation if at the time of committing the offence—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the proportion of alcohol in the person’s breath, blood or urine is tier 3; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: any concentration of a specified illicit drug is present in the person’s blood or urine. (Amended 24 of 2011 s. 7)

subsection.content: To avoid doubt and despite anything to the contrary in section 113C of the Criminal Procedure Ordinance (Cap. 221), the maximum fine for an offence under subsection (1) committed in circumstances of aggravation is the monetary amount derived by multiplying by 1.5 the maximum fine for the offence as set out in subsection (1).

The court or magistrate may deal with the conviction of an offence as a first conviction if, as at the date on which the offence was committed, at least 5 years have passed since the person’s last conviction under subsection (1).

subsection.leadIn: A person is to be regarded as driving dangerously within the meaning of subsection (1) if—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the way he or she drives falls far below what would be expected of a competent and careful driver; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: it would be obvious to a competent and careful driver that driving in that way would be dangerous.

subsection.content: A person is also to be regarded as driving dangerously within the meaning of subsection (1) if it would be obvious to a competent and careful driver that driving the motor vehicle concerned in its current state would be dangerous.
For the purposes of subsections (10) and (11), dangerous refers to danger either of injury to any person or of serious damage to property.

subsection.leadIn: For the purposes of subsections (10) and (11), in determining what would be expected of, or obvious to, a competent and careful driver in a particular case, regard must be had to all the circumstances of the case including—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the nature, condition and use of the road concerned at the material time;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the amount of traffic which is actually on the road concerned at the material time or which might reasonably be expected to be on the road concerned at the material time; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the circumstances (including the physical condition of the accused) of which the accused could be expected to be aware and any circumstances (including the physical condition of the accused) shown to have been within the knowledge of the accused.

subsection.content: In determining for the purposes of subsection (11) the state of the motor vehicle, regard may be had to anything attached to or carried on or in it and to the manner in which it is attached or carried.

If on the trial of any person charged with an offence under subsection (1) the prosecution proves that the person charged drove dangerously but not that he or she caused grievous bodily harm to another person by so driving, the person charged must be acquitted of the offence under subsection (1) and be found guilty of an offence under section 37.

On the trial of any person charged with an offence under subsection (1), the person charged may be acquitted of the offence under subsection (1) and be found guilty of one or more offences under section 38, 39, 39A, 39J, 39K or 39L. (Amended 24 of 2011 s. 7)

subsection.leadIn: A person who drives a motor vehicle on a road dangerously commits an offence and is liable—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: on conviction on indictment to a fine at level 4 and to imprisonment for 3 years;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: on summary conviction to a fine at level 3 and to imprisonment for 12 months.

subsection.content: If a court or magistrate convicts a person of an offence under subsection (1), the court or magistrate shall order that the person be disqualified in accordance with subsection (2A) or (2B) unless the court or magistrate for special reasons orders that the person be disqualified for a shorter period or that the person not be disqualified. (Replaced 23 of 2008 s. 6)

subsection.name: 2A
subsection.leadIn: Subject to subsection (2B), the person is to be disqualified—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: in the case of a first conviction, for a period of not less than 6 months; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: in the case of a second or subsequent conviction, for a period of not less than 2 years. (Added 23 of 2008 s. 6. Amended 19 of 2010 s. 8)

subsection.name: 2B
subsection.leadIn: If the court or magistrate has ordered the person to attend and complete a driving improvement course under section 72A(1A), the person is to be disqualified—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: in the case of a first conviction, for a period of not less than 6 months, or until the person has attended and completed the course at his own cost, whichever is the later; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: in the case of a second or subsequent conviction, for a period of not less than 2 years, or until the person has attended and completed the course at his own cost, whichever is the later. (Added 23 of 2008 s. 6. Amended 19 of 2010 s. 8)

subsection.name: 2C
subsection.leadIn: For the purposes of subsection (2), a person to whom subsection (2B) applies is disqualified for a shorter period if he is disqualified—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: in the case of a first conviction, for a period of less than 6 months, or until the person has attended and completed the driving improvement course at his own cost, whichever is the later; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: in the case of a second or subsequent conviction, for a period of less than 2 years, or until the person has attended and completed the driving improvement course at his own cost, whichever is the later. (Added 23 of 2008 s. 6. Amended 19 of 2010 s. 8)

subsection.name: 2D
subsection.content: If an offence under subsection (1) is committed in circumstances of aggravation, the maximum fine and term of imprisonment for the offence as set out in subsection (1), and the minimum disqualification periods for the offence as set out in subsections (2A) and (2B), are each increased by 50% and subsection (2C) must be construed accordingly. (Added 19 of 2010 s. 8)

subsection.name: 2E
subsection.leadIn: A person commits an offence under subsection (1) in circumstances of aggravation if at the time of committing the offence—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the proportion of alcohol in the person’s breath, blood or urine is tier 3; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: any concentration of a specified illicit drug is present in the person’s blood or urine. (Added 19 of 2010 s. 8. Amended 24 of 2011 s. 8)

subsection.name: 2F
subsection.content: To avoid doubt and despite anything to the contrary in section 113C of the Criminal Procedure Ordinance (Cap. 221), the maximum fine for an offence under subsection (1) committed in circumstances of aggravation is the monetary amount derived by multiplying by 1.5 the maximum fine for the offence as set out in subsection (1). (Added 19 of 2010 s. 8)

The court or magistrate may deal with the conviction of an offence as a first conviction if, as at the date on which the offence was committed, at least 5 years have elapsed since the person’s last conviction under subsection (1). (Replaced 23 of 2008 s. 6)

subsection.leadIn: A person is to be regarded as driving dangerously within the meaning of subsection (1) if—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the way he drives falls far below what would be expected of a competent and careful driver; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: it would be obvious to a competent and careful driver that driving in that way would be dangerous.

subsection.content: A person is also to be regarded as driving dangerously within the meaning of subsection (1) if it would be obvious to a competent and careful driver that driving the motor vehicle concerned in its current state would be dangerous.
For the purposes of subsections (4) and (5), dangerous refers to danger either of injury to any person or of serious damage to property.

subsection.leadIn: For the purposes of subsections (4) and (5), in determining what would be expected of, or obvious to, a competent and careful driver in a particular case, regard shall be had to all the circumstances of the case including—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the nature, condition and use of the road concerned at the material time;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the amount of traffic which is actually on the road concerned at the material time or which might reasonably be expected to be on the road concerned at the material time; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the circumstances (including the physical condition of the accused) of which the accused could be expected to be aware and any circumstances (including the physical condition of the accused) shown to have been within the knowledge of the accused.

subsection.content: In determining for the purposes of subsection (5) the state of the motor vehicle, regard may be had to anything attached to or carried on or in it and to the manner in which it is attached or carried.

On the trial of any person charged with an offence under subsection (1), the person charged may be acquitted of the offence under subsection (1) and be found guilty of one or more offences under section 38, 39, 39A, 39J, 39K or 39L. (Amended 24 of 2011 s. 8)
A person who drives a motor vehicle on a road carelessly commits an offence and is liable to a fine at level 2 and to imprisonment for 6 months. (Amended 33 of 2000 s. 3)
A person drives carelessly within the meaning of this section if on a road he drives a vehicle without due care and attention or without reasonable consideration for other persons using the road.

section.name: s39
section.heading: Driving a motor vehicle under the influence of drink

subsection.leadIn: A person who drives or attempts to drive or is in charge of a motor vehicle on any road while he is under the influence of drink to such an extent as to be incapable of having proper control of the motor vehicle commits an offence and is liable— (Amended 24 of 2011 s. 9)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: on conviction on indictment to a fine at level 4 and to imprisonment for 3 years; and (Amended 39 of 1995 s. 6)

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: on summary conviction on a first offence to a fine at level 3 and to imprisonment for 6 months and on a second or subsequent conviction or on a conviction subsequent to a conviction under section 39A, 39B or 39C to a fine at level 4 and to imprisonment for 12 months. (Replaced 39 of 1995 s. 6)

subsection.content: If a court or magistrate convicts a person of an offence under subsection (1), the court or magistrate shall order that the person be disqualified in accordance with subsection (2A) or (2B) unless the court or magistrate for special reasons orders that the person be disqualified for a shorter period or that the person not be disqualified. (Replaced 23 of 2008 s. 7)

subsection.name: 2A
subsection.leadIn: Subject to subsection (2B), the person is to be disqualified—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: in the case of a first conviction, for a period of not less than 2 years; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: in the case of a second or subsequent conviction, or a conviction subsequent to a conviction under section 39A, 39B or 39C, for a period of not less than 5 years. (Added 23 of 2008 s. 7. Amended 19 of 2010 s. 9)

subsection.name: 2B
subsection.leadIn: If the court or magistrate has ordered the person to attend and complete a driving improvement course under section 72A(1A), the person is to be disqualified—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: in the case of a first conviction, for a period of not less than 2 years, or until the person has attended and completed the course at his own cost, whichever is the later; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: in the case of a second or subsequent conviction, or a conviction subsequent to a conviction under section 39A, 39B or 39C, for a period of not less than 5 years, or until the person has attended and completed the course at his own cost, whichever is the later. (Added 23 of 2008 s. 7. Amended 19 of 2010 s. 9)

subsection.name: 2C
subsection.leadIn: For the purposes of subsection (2), a person to whom subsection (2B) applies is disqualified for a shorter period if he is disqualified—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: in the case of a first conviction, for a period of less than 2 years, or until the person has attended and completed the driving improvement course at his own cost, whichever is the later; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: in the case of a second or subsequent conviction, or a conviction subsequent to a conviction under section 39A, 39B or 39C, for a period of less than 5 years, or until the person has attended and completed the driving improvement course at his own cost, whichever is the later. (Added 23 of 2008 s. 7. Amended 19 of 2010 s. 9)

subsection.content: The court or magistrate may deal with the offence as a first offence, or the conviction of an offence as a first conviction if, as at the date on which the offence was committed, at least 5 years have elapsed since the person’s last conviction under subsection (1) or section 39A, 39B or 39C. (Replaced 23 of 2008 s. 7)

A person is deemed not to have been in charge of a motor vehicle if he proves that at the material time the circumstances were such that there was no likelihood of his driving the motor vehicle so long as he remained under the influence of drink to such an extent as to be incapable of having proper control of the motor vehicle. (Added 39 of 1995 s. 6. Amended 24 of 2011 s. 9)
The court or magistrate may, in determining whether there was such a likelihood as is mentioned in subsection (4), disregard any injury to him and any damage to the vehicle. (Added 39 of 1995 s. 6)

On the trial of a person charged with an offence under subsection (1), the person charged may be acquitted of the offence under subsection (1) and be found guilty of one or more offences under section 37 or 38. (Added 24 of 2011 s. 9)

section.name: s39A
section.heading: Driving, attempting to drive or being in charge of a motor vehicle with alcohol concentration above prescribed limit

subsection.leadIn: A person who drives or attempts to drive a motor vehicle, or is in charge of a motor vehicle, on any road with the proportion of alcohol in his breath, blood or urine exceeding the prescribed limit, commits an offence and is liable—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: on conviction on indictment to a fine at level 4 and to imprisonment for 3 years; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: on summary conviction on a first offence to a fine at level 3 and to imprisonment for 6 months and on a second or subsequent conviction or on a conviction subsequent to a conviction under section 39, 39B or 39C to a fine at level 4 and to imprisonment for 12 months.

subsection.name: 1A
subsection.leadIn: The proportion of alcohol in a person’s breath, blood or urine is—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: tier 1 if it exceeds the prescribed limit but is less than—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: for breath, 35 micrograms of alcohol in 100 millilitres of breath;

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: for blood, 80 milligrams of alcohol in 100 millilitres of blood; or

subparagraph.name: iii
subparagraph.content: for urine, 107 milligrams of alcohol in 100 millilitres of urine;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: tier 2 if it exceeds tier 1 but is less than—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: for breath, 66 micrograms of alcohol in 100 millilitres of breath;

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: for blood, 150 milligrams of alcohol in 100 millilitres of blood; or

subparagraph.name: iii
subparagraph.content: for urine, 201 milligrams of alcohol in 100 millilitres of urine;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: tier 3 if it exceeds tier 2. (Added 19 of 2010 s. 10)

subsection.content: If a court or magistrate convicts a person of an offence under subsection (1), the court or magistrate shall order that the person be disqualified in accordance with subsection (2A) or (2B) unless the court or magistrate for special reasons orders that the person be disqualified for a shorter period or that the person not be disqualified. (Replaced 23 of 2008 s. 8)

subsection.name: 2A
subsection.leadIn: Subject to subsection (2B), the period for which the person is to be disqualified is—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: for a first conviction, a period of not less than—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: 6 months if the proportion of alcohol in the person’s breath, blood or urine is tier 1;

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: 12 months if the proportion of alcohol in the person’s breath, blood or urine is tier 2;

subparagraph.name: iii
subparagraph.content: 2 years if the proportion of alcohol in the person’s breath, blood or urine is tier 3; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: for a second or subsequent conviction (regardless of the proportion of alcohol in the person’s breath, blood or urine on any previous conviction), or a conviction subsequent to a conviction under section 39, 39B or 39C, a period of not less than—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: 2 years if the proportion of alcohol in the person’s breath, blood or urine is tier 1;

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: 3 years if the proportion of alcohol in the person’s breath, blood or urine is tier 2;

subparagraph.name: iii
subparagraph.content: 5 years if the proportion of alcohol in the person’s breath, blood or urine is tier 3. (Replaced 19 of 2010 s. 10)

subsection.name: 2B
subsection.leadIn: If the court or magistrate has ordered the person to attend and complete a driving improvement course under section 72A(1A), the person is to be disqualified—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: in the case of a first conviction, for a period of not less than that specified in subsection (2A)(a) according to the proportion of alcohol in the person’s breath, blood or urine, or until the person has attended and completed the course at his own cost, whichever is the later; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: in the case of a second or subsequent conviction, or a conviction subsequent to a conviction under section 39, 39B or 39C, for a period of not less than that specified in subsection (2A)(b) according to the proportion of alcohol in the person’s breath, blood or urine, or until the person has attended and completed the course at his own cost, whichever is the later. (Added 23 of 2008 s. 8. Amended 19 of 2010 s. 10)

subsection.name: 2C
subsection.leadIn: For the purposes of subsection (2), a person to whom subsection (2B) applies is disqualified for a shorter period if he is disqualified—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: in the case of a first conviction, for a period of less than that specified in subsection (2A)(a) according to the proportion of alcohol in the person’s breath, blood or urine, or until the person has attended and completed the driving improvement course at his own cost, whichever is the later; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: in the case of a second or subsequent conviction, or a conviction subsequent to a conviction under section 39, 39B or 39C, for a period of less than that specified in subsection (2A)(b) according to the proportion of alcohol in the person’s breath, blood or urine, or until the person has attended and completed the driving improvement course at his own cost, whichever is the later. (Added 23 of 2008 s. 8. Amended 19 of 2010 s. 10)

subsection.content: The court or magistrate may deal with the offence as a first offence, or the conviction of an offence as a first conviction if, as at the date on which the offence was committed, at least 5 years have elapsed since the person’s last conviction under subsection (1) or section 39, 39B or 39C. (Replaced 23 of 2008 s. 8)

A person is deemed not to have been in charge of a motor vehicle if he proves that at the material time the circumstances were such that there was no likelihood of his driving the motor vehicle while the proportion of alcohol in his breath, blood or urine remained likely to exceed the prescribed limit.
The court or magistrate may, in determining whether there was such a likelihood as is mentioned in subsection (4), disregard any injury to him and any damage to the vehicle.

On the trial of a person charged with an offence under subsection (1), the person charged may be acquitted of the offence under subsection (1) and be found guilty of one or more offences under section 37 or 38. (Added 24 of 2011 s. 10)

subsection.leadIn: A police officer in uniform may require any of the following persons to provide a specimen of breath for a screening breath test—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a person who is driving or attempting to drive, or is in charge of, a motor vehicle on a road;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: a person whom the police officer has reasonable cause to suspect of—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: having been driving or attempting to drive, or been in charge of, a motor vehicle on a road with alcohol in his body, and still having alcohol in his body; or

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: having been driving or attempting to drive, or been in charge of, a motor vehicle on a road, and having committed a traffic offence while the vehicle was in motion. (Replaced 23 of 2008 s. 9)

subsection.name: 1A
subsection.leadIn: Subsection (1)(a) does not apply to a person if, immediately before the police officer requires him to provide the specimen of breath—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the person has, at the request of the police officer, provided a specimen of breath to be tested by an approved pre-screening device; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the test does not indicate that the proportion of alcohol in the person’s breath reaches such a level that it would be reasonable to suspect that such proportion is likely to exceed the prescribed limit. (Added 23 of 2008 s. 9)

subsection.content: If an accident occurs owing to the presence of a motor vehicle on any road, a police officer in uniform may require a person, whom the police officer has reasonable cause to suspect was driving or attempting to drive or in charge of the vehicle at the time of the accident, to provide a specimen of breath for a screening breath test.
A police officer in uniform may require a person to provide a specimen at or near the place where the requirement is made under subsection (1).

A police officer in uniform may require a person to provide a specimen under subsection (2) either at or near the place where the requirement is made or at a breath test centre, a police station or a hospital specified by the police officer. (Amended 50 of 1999 s. 3)
A police officer shall warn a person at the time of requiring a specimen for a screening breath test under this section that a failure to provide it may render him liable to prosecution.

subsection.leadIn: A person who, without reasonable excuse, fails to provide a specimen of breath when required under this section commits an offence and is liable—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: on conviction on indictment to a fine at level 4 and to imprisonment for 3 years; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: on summary conviction on a first offence to a fine at level 3 and to imprisonment for 6 months and on a second or subsequent conviction or on a conviction subsequent to a conviction under section 39, 39A or 39C to a fine at level 4 and to imprisonment for 12 months.

subsection.content: If a court or magistrate convicts a person of an offence under subsection (6), the court or magistrate shall order that the person be disqualified in accordance with subsection (7A) or (7B) unless the court or magistrate for special reasons orders that the person be disqualified for a shorter period or that the person not be disqualified. (Replaced 23 of 2008 s. 9)

subsection.name: 7A
subsection.leadIn: Subject to subsection (7B), the person is to be disqualified—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: in the case of a first conviction, for a period of not less than 2 years; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: in the case of a second or subsequent conviction, or a conviction subsequent to a conviction under section 39, 39A or 39C, for a period of not less than 5 years. (Added 23 of 2008 s. 9. Amended 19 of 2010 s. 11)

subsection.name: 7B
subsection.leadIn: If the court or magistrate has ordered the person to attend and complete a driving improvement course under section 72A(1A), the person is to be disqualified—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: in the case of a first conviction, for a period of not less than 2 years, or until the person has attended and completed the course at his own cost, whichever is the later; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: in the case of a second or subsequent conviction, or a conviction subsequent to a conviction under section 39, 39A or 39C, for a period of not less than 5 years, or until the person has attended and completed the course at his own cost, whichever is the later. (Added 23 of 2008 s. 9. Amended 19 of 2010 s. 11)

subsection.name: 7C
subsection.leadIn: For the purposes of subsection (7), a person to whom subsection (7B) applies is disqualified for a shorter period if he is disqualified—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: in the case of a first conviction, for a period of less than 2 years, or until the person has attended and completed the driving improvement course at his own cost, whichever is the later; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: in the case of a second or subsequent conviction, or a conviction subsequent to a conviction under section 39, 39A or 39C, for a period of less than 5 years, or until the person has attended and completed the driving improvement course at his own cost, whichever is the later. (Added 23 of 2008 s. 9. Amended 19 of 2010 s. 11)

subsection.content: The court or magistrate may deal with the offence as a first offence, or the conviction of an offence as a first conviction if, as at the date on which the offence was committed, at least 5 years have elapsed since the person’s last conviction under subsection (6) or section 39, 39A or 39C. (Replaced 23 of 2008 s. 9)

subsection.leadIn: A police officer in uniform may arrest a person without warrant if—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: as a result of a screening breath test he has reasonable cause to suspect that the proportion of alcohol in that person’s breath exceeds the prescribed limit; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the person has failed to provide a specimen of breath for a screening breath test when required to do so under this section.

subsection.leadIn: A person fails to provide a specimen for a screening breath test unless the specimen—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: is sufficient to enable the test to be carried out; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: is provided in a way to enable the objective of the test to be satisfactorily achieved.

section.name: s39C
section.heading: Provision of specimens for alcohol analysis

subsection.leadIn: A police officer may require a person whose screening breath test indicates that the proportion of alcohol in that person’s breath is likely to exceed the prescribed limit or who fails to provide a specimen for the screening breath test with reasonable excuse—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: to provide 2 specimens of breath for analysis by means of an approved breath analysing instrument; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: to provide a specimen of blood or urine for a laboratory test.

subsection.leadIn: The police officer shall decide that the person is to provide a specimen of blood or urine if—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the police officer has reasonable cause to believe that for medical reasons a specimen of breath cannot be provided or should not be required; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: at the time the requirement is made, an approved breath analysing instrument is not available at the breath test centre, the police station or the hospital where the requirement is made or it is for any other reason not practicable to use an approved breath analysing instrument. (Amended 50 of 1999 s. 4)

subsection.leadIn: Evidence of the proportion of alcohol in a specimen of breath, blood or urine may be given by the production of a document which purports to be either—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a statement automatically produced by the approved breath analysing instrument by which the proportion of alcohol in a specimen of breath was measured and a certificate signed by an approved operator (which may but need not be contained in the same document as the statement) certifying that the statement relates to a specimen provided by the accused at the date and time shown in the statement and that the approved breath analysing instrument was operated correctly and properly when the specimen of breath was being taken; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a certificate under section 25 of the Evidence Ordinance (Cap. 8) as to the proportion of alcohol found in a specimen of blood or urine identified in the certificate.

subsection.content: Evidence that a specimen of blood was taken from the accused with his consent by a medical practitioner, a registered nurse or an enrolled nurse may be given by the production of a document certifying that fact and purporting to be signed by the medical practitioner, the registered nurse or the enrolled nurse, as the case may be. (Amended 50 of 1999 s. 4)

Evidence that a specimen of urine was taken from the accused by a police officer or a medical practitioner may be given by the production of a document certifying that fact and purporting to be signed by a police officer or a medical practitioner, as the case may be.
A requirement under this section to provide a specimen of breath can only be made at a breath test centre, a police station or a hospital. (Amended 50 of 1999 s. 4)
A requirement under this section to provide a specimen of blood can only be made at a breath test centre, a police station or a hospital. (Amended 50 of 1999 s. 4)

A requirement under this section to provide a specimen of urine can only be made at a breath test centre, a police station or a hospital and the police officer making the requirement shall decide whether the specimen of urine is to be provided at a breath test centre, a police station or a hospital. (Amended 50 of 1999 s. 4)

The police officer requiring the provision of a specimen other than a specimen of breath under this section shall decide whether a specimen is to be of blood or of urine, but if a medical practitioner is of the opinion that for medical reasons a specimen of blood cannot or should not be taken the specimen shall be a specimen of urine.

If the police officer requires a person to provide a specimen of blood, the specimen of blood shall be taken by a medical practitioner, registered nurse or enrolled nurse specified by the police officer. (Amended 50 of 1999 s. 4)
Subject to subsection (11A), a specimen of blood must not be taken from a person unless the person consents to its being taken and it is so taken. (Replaced 24 of 2011 s. 12)

subsection.name: 11A
subsection.leadIn: A police officer may request a medical practitioner to take a specimen of blood from a person, if—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: he or she is a person the police officer is entitled to require—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: to provide a specimen of breath under section 39B(1)(b) or (2); or

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: to provide a specimen of blood under subsection (1)(b) or (2); and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: it appears to the police officer that—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: (if it is a person referred to in paragraph (a)(i)) he or she may be incapable of providing a specimen of breath and of giving a valid consent to the taking of a specimen of blood, and (if it is a person referred to in paragraph (a)(ii)) he or she may be incapable of giving a valid consent to the taking of a specimen of blood; and

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: the incapacity is attributable to medical reasons. (Added 24 of 2011 s. 12)

subsection.name: 11B
subsection.leadIn: It is lawful for a medical practitioner to whom a request is made under subsection (11A), if the medical practitioner thinks fit—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: to take a specimen of blood from the person; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: to provide the specimen to the police officer who made the request. (Added 24 of 2011 s. 12)

subsection.name: 11C
subsection.content: A specimen of blood may be taken pursuant to a request under subsection (11A) only at a breath test centre, a police station or a hospital. (Added 24 of 2011 s. 12)

subsection.name: 11D
subsection.leadIn: If a specimen of blood is taken pursuant to a request under subsection (11A), it must not be subjected to a laboratory test unless the person from whom it was taken—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: has been informed that it was taken;

paragraph.name: b
c
paragraph.content: has given that consent. (Added 24 of 2011 s. 12)

subsection.name: 11E
subsection.content: A police officer who makes a requirement referred to in subsection (11D)(b) must warn the person at the time of making the requirement that a failure to give consent may render the person liable to prosecution. (Added 24 of 2011 s. 12)

subsection.name: 11F
subsection.content: Evidence that a specimen of blood was taken from a person referred to in subsection (11A) by a medical practitioner may be given by the production of a document certifying that fact and purporting to be signed by the medical practitioner. (Added 24 of 2011 s. 12)

subsection.name: 11G
subsection.content: Evidence that a specimen of blood taken from a person under subsection (11B) was subjected to a laboratory test only after the person from whom it was taken was informed that it was taken and the person consented to the laboratory test may be given by the production of a document certifying that fact and purporting to be signed by the police officer who made the requirement referred to in subsection (11D)(b). (Added 24 of 2011 s. 12)

Evidence of the proportion of alcohol in a specimen of breath, blood or urine provided by the accused shall be evidence that the proportion of alcohol in the accused’s breath, blood or urine at the time of the alleged offence was not less than that in the specimen.

subsection.leadIn: Where, at the time a specimen of blood or urine was provided by the accused, he asked to be provided with such a specimen, evidence of the proportion of alcohol found in the specimen is not admissible on behalf of the prosecution unless—

paragraph.name: a
b
paragraph.content: the other part was supplied to the accused.

subsection.name: 13A
subsection.leadIn: If an accused from whom a specimen of blood was taken under subsection (11B), at the time he or she consented to its analysis, asked to be provided with a part of that specimen, evidence of the proportion of alcohol found in the specimen is not admissible on behalf of the prosecution unless—

paragraph.name: a
b
paragraph.content: the other part was supplied to the accused. (Added 24 of 2011 s. 12)

subsection.content: The person shall provide the specimen of urine within one hour of being required to provide it and after the provision of a previous specimen of urine.

subsection.leadIn: A person who, without reasonable excuse, fails to provide a specimen when required to do so under this section or fails to give consent under subsection (11D)(b) commits an offence and is liable— (Amended 24 of 2011 s. 12)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: on conviction on indictment to a fine at level 4 and to imprisonment for 3 years; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: on summary conviction on a first offence to a fine at level 3 and to imprisonment for 6 months and on a second or subsequent conviction or on a conviction subsequent to a conviction under section 39, 39A or 39B to a fine at level 4 and to imprisonment for 12 months.

subsection.content: If a court or magistrate convicts a person of an offence under subsection (15), the court or magistrate shall order that the person be disqualified in accordance with subsection (16A) or (16B) unless the court or magistrate for special reasons orders that the person be disqualified for a shorter period or that the person not be disqualified. (Replaced 23 of 2008 s. 10)

subsection.name: 16A
subsection.leadIn: Subject to subsection (16B), the person is to be disqualified—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: in the case of a first conviction, for a period of not less than 2 years; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: in the case of a second or subsequent conviction, or a conviction subsequent to a conviction under section 39, 39A or 39B, for a period of not less than 5 years. (Added 23 of 2008 s. 10. Amended 19 of 2010 s. 12)

subsection.name: 16B
subsection.leadIn: If the court or magistrate has ordered the person to attend and complete a driving improvement course under section 72A(1A), the person is to be disqualified—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: in the case of a first conviction, for a period of not less than 2 years, or until the person has attended and completed the course at his own cost, whichever is the later; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: in the case of a second or subsequent conviction, or a conviction subsequent to a conviction under section 39, 39A or 39B, for a period of not less than 5 years, or until the person has attended and completed the course at his own cost, whichever is the later. (Added 23 of 2008 s. 10. Amended 19 of 2010 s. 12)

subsection.name: 16C
subsection.leadIn: For the purposes of subsection (16), a person to whom subsection (16B) applies is disqualified for a shorter period if he is disqualified—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: in the case of a first conviction, for a period of less than 2 years, or until the person has attended and completed the driving improvement course at his own cost, whichever is the later; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: in the case of a second or subsequent conviction, or a conviction subsequent to a conviction under section 39, 39A or 39B, for a period of less than 5 years, or until the person has attended and completed the driving improvement course at his own cost, whichever is the later. (Added 23 of 2008 s. 10. Amended 19 of 2010 s. 12)

subsection.content: The court or magistrate may deal with the offence as a first offence, or the conviction of an offence as a first conviction if, as at the date on which the offence was committed, at least 5 years have elapsed since the person’s last conviction under subsection (15) or section 39, 39A or 39B. (Replaced 23 of 2008 s. 10)
A police officer shall warn a person at the time of requiring a specimen under this section that a failure to provide it may render him liable to prosecution.

subsection.leadIn: A person fails to provide a specimen of breath, blood or urine for analysis or laboratory test unless the specimen—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: is sufficient to enable the analysis or laboratory test to be carried out; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: is provided in a way to enable the objective of the analysis or laboratory test to be satisfactorily achieved.

subsection.content: The Commissioner of Police may by notice in the Gazette designate a place or vehicle to be a breath test centre. (Added 50 of 1999 s. 4)
For the avoidance of doubt, a notice under subsection (20) is not subsidiary legislation. (Added 50 of 1999 s. 4)

subsection.def: For the purposes of this section, registered nurse (註冊護士) and enrolled nurse (登記護士) have the respective meanings assigned to them by section 2 of the Nurses Registration Ordinance (Cap. 164). (Added 50 of 1999 s. 4)

subsection.content: The court or magistrate shall use the statement referred to in section 39C(3)(a) relating to the specimen with the lower proportion of alcohol out of the 2 specimens of breath a person provides under section 39C and shall disregard the other.

A person at a hospital as a patient shall not be required to provide a specimen of breath for a screening breath test or breath analysis, a specimen of oral fluid for a Rapid Oral Fluid Test, or a specimen of blood or urine for a laboratory test unless the medical practitioner in immediate charge of his case has been notified of the proposal to make the requirement. (Amended 24 of 2011 s. 13)
A requirement made after the medical practitioner has been notified under subsection (1) is a requirement for the provision of a specimen at a hospital.
The requirement shall not be made if the medical practitioner objects on the ground specified in subsection (4) and states in writing the diagnosis justifying the objection.

The ground on which the medical practitioner may object under subsection (3) is that the requirement or the provision of a specimen of breath for the screening breath test or breath analysis, a specimen of oral fluid for a Rapid Oral Fluid Test, a specimen of oral fluid for a Rapid Oral Fluid Test or a specimen of blood or urine for the laboratory test would be prejudicial to the proper care and treatment of the patient. (Amended 24 of 2011 s. 13)
To avoid doubt, this section does not apply to the taking of a specimen of blood from a person falling within section 39C(11A) or 39Q(1). (Added 24 of 2011 s. 13)

subsection.leadIn: The Commissioner of Police may by notice in the Gazette approve types of instruments as—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: an approved breath analysing instrument to analyse the proportion of alcohol in a specimen of a person’s breath;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: an approved screening device for the purpose of indicating whether the proportion of alcohol in a person’s breath is likely to exceed the prescribed limit; (Amended 23 of 2008 s. 11)

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: an approved pre-screening device for indicating whether or not the proportion of alcohol in a person’s breath reaches such a level that it would be reasonable to suspect that such proportion is likely to exceed the prescribed limit. (Added 23 of 2008 s. 11)
