subsection.content: The Commissioner of Police may authorize in writing members of the police force as approved operators to carry out breath analysis using an approved breath analysing instrument.

subsection.def: The Secretary may by notice in the Gazette amend the definition of prescribed limit (訂明限度) by varying the proportion of alcohol that constitutes the prescribed limit. (Amended L.N. 106 of 2002; L.N. 130 of 2007; 6 of 2012 s. 2)

subsection.content: Notice of a variation in the prescribed limit will not come into operation until after the time provided for the Legislative Council to debate the notice under section 34 of the Interpretation and General Clauses Ordinance (Cap. 1) has expired.

section.name: s39H
section.heading: Amendment of tier 1, tier 2 or tier 3

subsection.content: The Secretary may by notice in the Gazette amend section 39A(1A) by varying the proportion of alcohol that constitutes tier 1, tier 2 or tier 3. (Amended 6 of 2012 s. 2)

A notice under subsection (1) is not to come into operation until after the time provided for the Legislative Council to debate the notice under section 34 of the Interpretation and General Clauses Ordinance (Cap. 1) has expired.
The Secretary may by notice in the Gazette amend Schedule 1A. (Amended 6 of 2012 s. 2)

A notice under subsection (1) is not to come into operation until after the time provided for the Legislative Council to debate the notice under section 34 of the Interpretation and General Clauses Ordinance (Cap. 1) has expired.

section.name: s39J
section.heading: Driving motor vehicle without proper control under influence of specified illicit drug

subsection.leadIn: A person who drives or attempts to drive, or is in charge of, a motor vehicle on any road while he or she is under the influence of a specified illicit drug to such an extent as to be incapable of having proper control of the motor vehicle commits an offence and is liable—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: on conviction on indictment, to a fine at level 4 and to imprisonment for 3 years; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: on summary conviction—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: on a first offence under this subsection, to a fine at level 3 and to imprisonment for 6 months;

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: subsequent to a conviction on indictment under this subsection, to a fine at level 4 and to imprisonment for 12 months;

subparagraph.name: iii
subparagraph.content: subsequent to a summary conviction under this subsection, to a fine at level 4 and to imprisonment for 12 months; or

subparagraph.name: iv
subparagraph.content: subsequent to a conviction under section 39K, 39L, 39O(1) or 39S, to a fine at level 4 and to imprisonment for 12 months.

subsection.content: If a court or magistrate convicts a person of an offence under subsection (1), the court or magistrate must order that the person be disqualified in accordance with subsection (3) or (5) unless the court or magistrate for special reasons orders that the person be disqualified for a shorter period or that the person not be disqualified.

subsection.leadIn: Subject to subsection (5), the period for which the person is to be disqualified—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: for a first conviction, is a period of not less than 5 years; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: for a subsequent conviction, is a period of not less than 10 years.

subsection.leadIn: A court or magistrate may, on convicting a person under subsection (1), in making an order that he or she be disqualified in accordance with subsection (3), order that the person be disqualified for life, if—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the person has been convicted of the same offence previously; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: having regard to the circumstances in which the offence was committed and the behaviour of the person, the court or magistrate is of the opinion that it is undesirable for the person to continue to be allowed to drive a motor vehicle.

subsection.leadIn: If the court or magistrate has ordered a person to attend and complete a driving improvement course under section 72A(1A), the person is to be disqualified—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: for a first conviction, for a period of not less than 5 years, or until the person has attended and completed the course at his or her own cost, whichever is the later; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: for a subsequent conviction, for a period of not less than 10 years, or until the person has attended and completed the course at his or her own cost, whichever is the later.

subsection.leadIn: For the purposes of subsection (2), a person to whom subsection (5) applies is disqualified for a shorter period if the period for which he or she is disqualified—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: for a first conviction, is a period of less than 5 years, or until the person has attended and completed the driving improvement course at his or her own cost, whichever is the later; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: for a subsequent conviction, is a period of less than 10 years, or until the person has attended and completed the driving improvement course at his or her own cost, whichever is the later.

subsection.content: The court or magistrate may deal with the offence as a first offence, or the conviction of an offence as a first conviction (including for the purposes of subsection (4)(a)), if, as at the date on which the offence was committed, at least 5 years have passed since the person’s last conviction under subsection (1) or section 39K, 39L, 39O(1) or 39S.

A person is taken not to have been in charge of a motor vehicle if he or she proves that at the material time the circumstances were such that there was no likelihood of the person’s driving the motor vehicle so long as he or she remained under the influence of a specified illicit drug to such an extent as to be incapable of having proper control of the motor vehicle.
The court or magistrate may, in determining whether there was such a likelihood as is mentioned in subsection (8), disregard any injury to the person and any damage to the motor vehicle.

subsection.leadIn: For the purposes of subsection (1), a person is under the influence of a specified illicit drug to such an extent as to be incapable of having proper control of the motor vehicle if—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the person’s ability to drive properly is for the time being impaired; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the concentration of the specified illicit drug or of the combination of such drugs present in the person’s blood or urine and to which the charge relates would usually result in a person being unable to drive properly.

subsection.leadIn: It is a defence for a person charged under subsection (1) to prove that—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the specified illicit drug or the combination of such drugs found in the person’s blood or urine and to which the charge relates was lawfully obtained;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: he or she did not know and could not reasonably have known that the lawfully obtained specified illicit drug or the combination of such drugs found in the blood or urine would render him or her incapable of having proper control of a motor vehicle if consumed or used in accordance with advice; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: he or she consumed or used that drug or combination of those drugs in accordance with that advice.

subsection.leadIn: If on the trial of a person charged with an offence under subsection (1), the prosecution proves that the person drove or attempted to drive, or was in charge of, the motor vehicle on a road, and—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: that a specified illicit drug was present in the person’s blood or urine but not that he or she was under the influence of the drug to such an extent as to be incapable of having proper control of the motor vehicle, the person charged must be acquitted of the offence under subsection (1) but may be found guilty of an offence under section 39K; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: that the person was under the influence of a drug, but not a specified illicit drug, to such an extent as to be incapable of having proper control of the motor vehicle, the person charged must be acquitted of the offence under subsection (1) but may be found guilty of an offence under section 39L.

subsection.content: On the trial of a person charged with an offence under subsection (1), the person charged may be acquitted of the offence under subsection (1) and be found guilty of one or more offences under section 37 or 38 and, to avoid doubt, subsection (11) does not apply to those offences.

For the purposes of subsection (11), a specified illicit drug is lawfully obtained if it is a specified illicit drug that is prescribed for or administered or supplied to an accused person by a healthcare professional.

subsection.leadIn: In this section—
subsection.def: advice (指示) means, in relation to a drug that is referred to in subsection (14), written or oral advice given to an accused person by the healthcare professional who prescribed, administered or supplied the drug;
first conviction (首次定罪) means a conviction on a first offence under subsection (1) (whether a conviction on indictment or a summary conviction);

def.name: HealthcareProfessional
def.leadIn: healthcare professional (醫護專業人員) means—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a medical practitioner;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a registered dentist as defined by section 2(1) of the Dentists Registration Ordinance (Cap. 156);

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: a person whose name is entered on the register of pharmacists under section 5 of the Pharmacy and Poisons Ordinance (Cap. 138); or

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: a person acting under the direction or supervision of a person referred to in paragraph (a), (b) or (c);

def.name: SubsequentConviction
def.leadIn: subsequent conviction (再次定罪) means—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a conviction subsequent to a first conviction; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a conviction referred to in subsection (1)(b)(ii), (iii) or (iv).

section.name: s39K
section.heading: Driving motor vehicle with any concentration of specified illicit drug

subsection.leadIn: A person who drives or attempts to drive, or is in charge of, a motor vehicle on any road while any concentration of a specified illicit drug is present in the person’s blood or urine (whether or not any other drug is also so present) commits an offence and is liable—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: on conviction on indictment, to a fine at level 4 and to imprisonment for 3 years; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: on summary conviction—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: on a first offence under this subsection, to a fine at level 3 and to imprisonment for 6 months;

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: subsequent to a conviction on indictment under this subsection, to a fine at level 4 and to imprisonment for 12 months;

subparagraph.name: iii
subparagraph.content: subsequent to a summary conviction under this subsection, to a fine at level 4 and to imprisonment for 12 months; or

subparagraph.name: iv
subparagraph.content: subsequent to a conviction under section 39J, 39L, 39O(1) or 39S, to a fine at level 4 and to imprisonment for 12 months.

subsection.content: If a court or magistrate convicts a person of an offence under subsection (1), the court or magistrate must order that the person be disqualified in accordance with subsection (3) or (4) unless the court or magistrate for special reasons orders that the person be disqualified for a shorter period or that the person not be disqualified.

subsection.leadIn: Subject to subsection (4), the period for which the person is to be disqualified—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: for a first conviction, is a period of not less than 2 years; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: for a subsequent conviction, is a period of not less than 5 years.

subsection.leadIn: If the court or magistrate has ordered the person to attend and complete a driving improvement course under section 72A(1A), the person is to be disqualified—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: for a first conviction, for a period of not less than 2 years, or until the person has attended and completed the course at his or her own cost, whichever is the later; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: for a subsequent conviction, for a period of not less than 5 years, or until the person has attended and completed the course at his or her own cost, whichever is later.

subsection.leadIn: For the purposes of subsection (2), a person to whom subsection (4) applies is disqualified for a shorter period if the period for which he or she is disqualified—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: for a first conviction, is a period of less than 2 years, or until the person has attended and completed the driving improvement course at his or her own cost, whichever is the later; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: for a subsequent conviction, is a period of less than 5 years, or until the person has attended and completed the driving improvement course at his or her own cost, whichever is the later.

subsection.content: The court or magistrate may deal with the offence as a first offence, or the conviction of an offence as a first conviction, if, as at the date on which the offence was committed, at least 5 years have passed since the person’s last conviction under subsection (1) or section 39J, 39L, 39O(1) or 39S.

subsection.leadIn: It is a defence for a person charged under subsection (1) to prove that—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: if only one specified illicit drug was present in his or her blood or urine, that drug; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: if more than one specified illicit drug was present in his or her blood or urine, every such drug,

subsection.continued: was a specified illicit drug that was prescribed for or administered or supplied to the person by a healthcare professional.

subsection.content: A person is taken not to have been in charge of a motor vehicle if he or she proves that at the material time the circumstances were such that there was no likelihood of the person’s driving the motor vehicle so long as any concentration of a specified illicit drug was present in his or her blood or urine.
The court or magistrate may, in determining whether there was such a likelihood as is mentioned in subsection (8), disregard any injury to the person and any damage to the motor vehicle.

On the trial of a person charged with an offence under subsection (1), the person charged may be acquitted of the offence under subsection (1) and be found guilty of one or more offences under section 37 or 38 and, to avoid doubt, subsection (7) does not apply to those offences.

subsection.leadIn: In this section—
subsection.def: first conviction (首次定罪) means a conviction on a first offence under subsection (1) (whether a conviction on indictment or a summary conviction);
healthcare professional (醫護專業人員) has the meaning given by section 39J(15);

def.name: SubsequentConviction
def.leadIn: subsequent conviction (再次定罪) means—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a conviction subsequent to a first conviction; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a conviction referred to in subsection (1)(b)(ii), (iii) or (iv).

subsection.content: In this section a reference to a conviction for an offence under subsection (1) includes a conviction pursuant to section 39J(12)(a).

section.name: s39L
section.heading: Driving motor vehicle without proper control under influence of drug other than specified illicit drug

subsection.leadIn: A person who drives or attempts to drive, or is in charge of, a motor vehicle on any road while he or she is under the influence of a drug other than a specified illicit drug (non-specified drug) to such an extent as to be incapable of having proper control of the motor vehicle commits an offence and is liable—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: on conviction on indictment, to a fine at level 4 and to imprisonment for 3 years; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: on summary conviction—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: on a first offence under this subsection, to a fine at level 3 and to imprisonment for 6 months;

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: subsequent to a conviction on indictment under this subsection, to a fine at level 4 and to imprisonment for 12 months;

subparagraph.name: iii
subparagraph.content: subsequent to a summary conviction under this subsection, to a fine at level 4 and to imprisonment for 12 months; or

subparagraph.name: iv
subparagraph.content: subsequent to a conviction under section 39J, 39K, 39O(1) or 39S, to a fine at level 4 and to imprisonment for 12 months.

subsection.content: If a court or magistrate convicts a person of an offence under subsection (1), the court or magistrate must order that the person be disqualified in accordance with subsection (3) or (4) unless the court or magistrate for special reasons orders that the person be disqualified for a shorter period or that the person not be disqualified.

subsection.leadIn: Subject to subsection (4), the period for which the person is to be disqualified—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: for a first conviction, is a period of not less than 6 months; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: for a subsequent conviction, is a period of not less than 2 years.

subsection.leadIn: If the court or magistrate has ordered a person to attend and complete a driving improvement course under section 72A(1A), the person is to be disqualified—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: for a first conviction, for a period of not less than 6 months, or until the person has attended and completed the course at his or her own cost, whichever is the later; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: for a subsequent conviction, for a period of not less than 2 years, or until the person has attended and completed the course at his or her own cost, whichever is the later.

subsection.leadIn: For the purposes of subsection (2), a person to whom subsection (4) applies is disqualified for a shorter period if the period for which he or she is disqualified—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: for a first conviction, is a period of less than 6 months, or until the person has attended and completed the driving improvement course at his or her own cost, whichever is the later; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: for a subsequent conviction, is a period of less than 2 years, or until the person has attended and completed the driving improvement course at his or her own cost, whichever is the later.

subsection.content: The court or magistrate may deal with the offence as a first offence, or the conviction of an offence as a first conviction, if, as at the date on which the offence was committed, at least 5 years have passed since the person’s last conviction under subsection (1) or section 39J, 39K, 39O(1) or 39S.

A person is taken not to have been in charge of a motor vehicle if he or she proves that at the material time the circumstances were such that there was no likelihood of the person’s driving the motor vehicle so long as he or she remained under the influence of a non-specified drug to such an extent as to be incapable of having proper control of the motor vehicle.
The court or magistrate may, in determining whether there was such a likelihood as is mentioned in subsection (7), disregard any injury to the person and any damage to the motor vehicle.

subsection.leadIn: For the purposes of subsection (1), a person is under the influence of a non-specified drug to such an extent as to be incapable of having proper control of the motor vehicle if—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the person’s ability to drive properly is for the time being impaired; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the concentration of the non-specified drug or of the combination of such drugs present in the person’s blood or urine and to which the charge relates would usually result in a person being unable to drive properly.

subsection.leadIn: It is a defence for a person charged under subsection (1) to prove that—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the non-specified drug or the combination of such drugs found in the person’s blood or urine and to which the charge relates was lawfully obtained;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: he or she did not know and could not reasonably have known that the lawfully obtained non-specified drug or the combination of such drugs found in the blood or urine would render him or her incapable of having proper control of a motor vehicle if consumed or used in accordance with advice; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: he or she consumed or used that drug or combination of those drugs in accordance with that advice.

subsection.content: On the trial of a person charged with an offence under subsection (1), the person charged may be acquitted of the offence under subsection (1) and be found guilty of one or more offences under section 37 or 38 and, to avoid doubt, subsection (10) does not apply to those offences.

subsection.leadIn: For the purposes of subsection (10), a non-specified drug is lawfully obtained if it is—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a non-specified drug that is prescribed for or administered or supplied to an accused person by a healthcare professional;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: a non-specified drug that is a pharmaceutical product as defined by section 2(1) of the Pharmacy and Poisons Ordinance (Cap. 138)—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: that is registered as mentioned in regulation 36 of the Pharmacy and Poisons Regulations (Cap. 138 sub. leg. A); and

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: for the sale of which a prescription is not required by Hong Kong law; or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: a non-specified drug that is a proprietary Chinese medicine, as defined by section 2(1) of the Chinese Medicine Ordinance (Cap. 549), that is registered under section 121 of that Ordinance.

subsection.leadIn: In this section—

def.name: Advice
def.leadIn: advice (指示) means, in relation to a drug that is referred to in—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: subsection (12)(a)—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: written or oral advice given to an accused person by the healthcare professional who prescribed, administered or supplied the drug; and

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: information written on a label, as defined by section 2(1) of the Pharmacy and Poisons Ordinance (Cap. 138), accompanying the prescribed or supplied drug;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: subsection (12)(b), any information written on a label referred to in paragraph (a)(ii) accompanying the drug; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: subsection (12)(c), any information on the package insert, as defined by section 2(1) of the Chinese Medicine Ordinance (Cap. 549), supplied with the drug;

subsection.def: first conviction (首次定罪) means a conviction on a first offence under subsection (1) (whether a conviction on indictment or a summary conviction);

def.name: HealthcareProfessional
def.leadIn: healthcare professional (醫護專業人員) means—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a medical practitioner;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a registered dentist as defined by section 2(1) of the Dentists Registration Ordinance (Cap. 156);

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: a registered Chinese medicine practitioner or a listed Chinese medicine practitioner, as defined by section 2(1) of the Chinese Medicine Ordinance (Cap. 549);

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: a person whose name is entered on the register of pharmacists under section 5 of the Pharmacy and Poisons Ordinance (Cap. 138); or

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: a person acting under the direction or supervision of a person referred to in paragraph (a), (b), (c) or (d);

def.name: SubsequentConviction
def.leadIn: subsequent conviction (再次定罪) means—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a conviction subsequent to a first conviction; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a conviction referred to in subsection (1)(b)(ii), (iii) or (iv).

subsection.content: In this section a reference to a conviction for an offence under subsection (1) includes a conviction pursuant to section 39J(12)(b).

section.name: s39M
section.heading: Persons who may be required to undergo preliminary drug test

subsection.leadIn: A police officer may require a person referred to in subsection (2) to undergo one or more of the following—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a Drug Influence Recognition Observation;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: an Impairment Test;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: a Rapid Oral Fluid Test.

subsection.leadIn: A person who may be required to undergo a preliminary drug test under subsection (1) is any person whom the police officer has reasonable cause to suspect—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: has been driving or attempting to drive, or has been in charge of, a motor vehicle on a road while any concentration of a specified illicit drug was present in his or her blood or urine or while under the influence of any drug; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: has been driving or attempting to drive, or has been in charge of, a motor vehicle on a road and has committed a traffic offence while the motor vehicle was in motion.

subsection.content: If an accident occurs owing to the presence of a motor vehicle on a road, a police officer may require a person, whom the police officer has reasonable cause to suspect was driving or attempting to drive, or was in charge of, the motor vehicle at the time of the accident, to undergo one or more preliminary drug tests.

subsection.leadIn: A person is not obliged to undergo an Impairment Test under subsection (1) or (3) if—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: immediately before the requirement to undergo such a test is made, he or she, on being required by a police officer, had undergone a Drug Influence Recognition Observation; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the authorized police officer who carried out the Drug Influence Recognition Observation did not form an opinion that he or she was under the influence of a drug.

subsection.content: An authorized police officer may require a person referred to in subsection (2) or (3) to provide one or more specimens of oral fluid to carry out a Rapid Oral Fluid Test.

subsection.leadIn: A police officer or an authorized police officer who makes a requirement under subsection (1), (3) or (5) must warn the person at the time of making the requirement that—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a failure to provide the specimen or specimens he or she is required to provide may render him or her liable to prosecution;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: he or she may be required to undergo more than one of the preliminary drug tests referred to in subsection (1); and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: a failure to undergo any of those tests he or she is required to undergo may render him or her liable to prosecution.

subsection.content: A Drug Influence Recognition Observation or a Rapid Oral Fluid Test may be carried out at or near the place where the requirement is made.
An Impairment Test must be carried out at a police station specified by the police officer who makes the requirement.

subsection.leadIn: Evidence whether an accused person’s ability to drive properly was impaired by the consumption or use of a drug may be given by the production of a document purporting to—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: be the opinion of the authorized police officer who carried out the Impairment Test as to whether the person’s ability to drive properly was impaired; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: be signed by the authorized police officer who carried out the Impairment Test.

section.name: s39N
section.heading: Drivers may be required to undergo Rapid Oral Fluid Test

subsection.content: A police officer may require a person who is driving or attempting to drive, or is in charge of, a motor vehicle on a road, to undergo a Rapid Oral Fluid Test to detect whether any specified illicit drug is present in his or her oral fluid.
An authorized police officer may require a person referred to in subsection (1) to provide one or more specimens of oral fluid to carry out a Rapid Oral Fluid Test.

An authorized police officer who makes a requirement under subsection (2) must warn the person at the time of making the requirement that a failure to provide the specimen or specimens he or she is required to provide may render him or her liable to prosecution.
A Rapid Oral Fluid Test may be carried out at or near the place where the requirement is made.

section.name: s39O
section.heading: Failure to undergo preliminary drug test

subsection.leadIn: A person who, without reasonable excuse, fails to undergo an Impairment Test or to provide a specimen or specimens (if more than one is required) of oral fluid to carry out a Rapid Oral Fluid Test when required to do so under section 39M or 39N commits an offence and is liable—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: on conviction on indictment, to a fine at level 4 and to imprisonment for 3 years; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: on summary conviction—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: on a first offence under this subsection, to a fine at level 3 and to imprisonment for 6 months;

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: subsequent to a conviction on indictment under this subsection, to a fine at level 4 and to imprisonment for 12 months;

subparagraph.name: iii
subparagraph.content: subsequent to a summary conviction under this subsection, to a fine at level 4 and to imprisonment for 12 months; or

subparagraph.name: iv
subparagraph.content: subsequent to a conviction under section 39J, 39K, 39L or 39S, to a fine at level 4 and to imprisonment for 12 months.

subsection.leadIn: Without limiting subsection (1), a person fails to provide any specimen of oral fluid unless the specimen—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: is sufficient to enable the Rapid Oral Fluid Test to be carried out; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: is provided in a way to enable the objective of the test to be satisfactorily achieved.

subsection.content: A person who, without reasonable excuse, fails to undergo a Drug Influence Recognition Observation when required to do so under section 39M commits an offence and is liable on conviction to a fine at level 1 and to imprisonment for 3 months.

If a court or magistrate convicts a person of an offence under subsection (1), the court or magistrate must order that the person be disqualified in accordance with subsection (5) or (6) unless the court or magistrate for special reasons orders that the person be disqualified for a shorter period or that the person not be disqualified.

subsection.leadIn: Subject to subsection (6), the period for which the person is to be disqualified—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: for a first conviction, is a period of not less than 5 years; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: for a subsequent conviction, is a period of not less than 10 years.

subsection.leadIn: If the court or magistrate has ordered the person to attend and complete a driving improvement course under section 72A(1A), the person is to be disqualified—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: for a first conviction, for a period of not less than 5 years, or until the person has attended and completed the course at his or her own cost, whichever is the later; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: for a subsequent conviction, for a period of not less than 10 years, or until the person has attended and completed the course at his or her own cost, whichever is the later.

subsection.leadIn: For the purposes of subsection (4), a person to whom subsection (6) applies is disqualified for a shorter period if the period for which he or she is disqualified—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: for a first conviction, is a period of less than 5 years, or until the person has attended and completed the driving improvement course at his or her own cost, whichever is the later; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: for a subsequent conviction, is a period of less than 10 years, or until the person has attended and completed the driving improvement course at his or her own cost, whichever is the later.

subsection.content: The court or magistrate may deal with the offence as a first offence, or the conviction of an offence as a first conviction, if, as at the date on which the offence was committed, at least 5 years have passed since the person’s last conviction under subsection (1) or section 39J, 39K, 39L or 39S.

subsection.leadIn: A police officer may arrest a person without a warrant if—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: as a result of a Rapid Oral Fluid Test carried out on the person, the police officer has reasonable cause to suspect that any concentration of a specified illicit drug is present in his or her oral fluid;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: as a result of a Drug Influence Recognition Observation carried out on the person, the police officer has reasonable cause to suspect that he or she has committed an offence under section 39J(1), 39K(1) or 39L(1);

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: as a result of an Impairment Test carried out on the person, the police officer has reasonable cause to suspect that he or she has committed an offence under section 39J(1), 39K(1) or 39L(1);

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: he or she fails to undergo a Drug Influence Recognition Observation when required to do so under section 39M;

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: he or she fails to undergo an Impairment Test when required to do so under section 39M; or

paragraph.name: f
paragraph.content: he or she fails to provide a specimen or specimens of oral fluid to carry out a Rapid Oral Fluid Test when required to do so under section 39M or 39N.

subsection.leadIn: In this section—
subsection.def: first conviction (首次定罪) means a conviction on a first offence under subsection (1) (whether a conviction on indictment or a summary conviction);

def.name: SubsequentConviction
def.leadIn: subsequent conviction (再次定罪) means—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a conviction subsequent to a first conviction; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a conviction referred to in subsection (1)(b)(ii), (iii) or (iv).

section.name: s39P
section.heading: Provision of specimen for drug analysis

subsection.content: A police officer may require a person to provide a specimen of blood or urine, or specimens both of blood and urine, for a laboratory test, if the results of the Rapid Oral Fluid Test carried out on the person indicate that any concentration of a specified illicit drug is present in his or her oral fluid.

An authorized police officer who has carried out an Impairment Test on a person may require the person to provide a specimen of blood or urine, or specimens both of blood and urine, for a laboratory test, if the police officer is of the opinion that the results of the Impairment Test indicate that his or her ability to drive properly is for the time being impaired.

subsection.leadIn: A police officer may require a person on whom a preliminary drug test could not be carried out due to a medical reason or any other reasonable cause, to provide a specimen of blood or urine, or specimens both of blood and urine, for a laboratory test, if the police officer has reasonable cause to suspect that—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: any concentration of a specified illicit drug is present in his or her blood, urine or oral fluid; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: he or she is under the influence of any drug.

subsection.content: A requirement to provide any specimen under subsection (1), (2) or (3) can only be made at a breath test centre, a police station or a hospital.

A police officer or an authorized police officer who makes a requirement under subsection (1), (2) or (3) must decide whether the specimen is to be of blood or urine or whether both blood and urine specimens are to be taken, but if a medical practitioner is of the opinion that for medical reasons a specimen of blood cannot or should not be taken, only a specimen of urine may be taken.
A specimen of blood under subsection (1), (2) or (3) may only be taken by a medical practitioner, a registered nurse or an enrolled nurse, specified by a police officer in each case.
A person must provide the specimen of urine within 1 hour of being required to provide it.

A police officer or an authorized police officer who makes a requirement under this section must warn the person at the time of requiring the specimen that a failure to provide it may render him or her liable to prosecution.
Subject to section 39Q, a specimen of blood must not be taken from a person unless he or she consents to its being taken and it is so taken.

Evidence that a specimen of blood was taken from the accused person with his or her consent by a medical practitioner, a registered nurse or an enrolled nurse may be given by the production of a document certifying that fact and purporting to be signed by the medical practitioner, the registered nurse or the enrolled nurse.

Evidence that a specimen of urine was taken from the accused person by a police officer or a medical practitioner may be given by the production of a document certifying that fact and purporting to be signed by the police officer or the medical practitioner.

subsection.leadIn: In this section—
subsection.def: enrolled nurse (登記護士) has the meaning given by section 2(1) of the Nurses Registration Ordinance (Cap. 164);
registered nurse (註冊護士) has the meaning given by section 2(1) of the Nurses Registration Ordinance (Cap. 164).

section.name: s39Q
section.heading: Specimens of blood from persons incapable of consenting

subsection.leadIn: A police officer may request a medical practitioner to take a specimen of blood from a person, if—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: he or she is a person the police officer is entitled to require—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: to undergo a preliminary drug test under section 39M(1) or (3); or

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: to provide a specimen of blood under section 39P(1), (2) or (3); and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: it appears to the police officer that—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: (if it is a person referred to in paragraph (a)(i)) he or she may be incapable of undergoing a preliminary drug test and of giving a valid consent to the taking of a specimen of blood, and (if it is a person referred to in paragraph (a)(ii)) he or she may be incapable of giving a valid consent to the taking of a specimen of blood; and

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: the incapacity is attributable to medical reasons.

subsection.leadIn: It is lawful for a medical practitioner to whom a request is made under subsection (1), if the medical practitioner thinks fit—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: to take a specimen of blood from the person; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: to provide the specimen to the police officer who made the request.

subsection.content: A specimen of blood may be taken pursuant to a request under subsection (1) only at a breath test centre, a police station or a hospital.

subsection.leadIn: If a specimen of blood is taken pursuant to a request under this section, it must not be subjected to a laboratory test unless the person from whom it was taken—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: has been informed that it was taken;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: has been required by a police officer to give consent to the analysis of the specimen for the purpose of evidence in the relevant investigation; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: has given that consent.

subsection.content: A police officer who makes a requirement referred to in subsection (4)(b) must warn the person at the time of making the requirement that a failure to give consent may render him or her liable to prosecution.

Evidence that a specimen of blood was taken from a person referred to in subsection (1) by a medical practitioner may be given by the production of a document certifying that fact and purporting to be signed by the medical practitioner.

Evidence that a specimen of blood taken from a person under this section was subjected to a laboratory test only after the person from whom it was taken was informed that it was taken and he or she consented to the laboratory test may be given by the production of a document certifying that fact and purporting to be signed by the police officer who made the requirement referred to in subsection (4)(b).

A specimen of blood or urine taken under section 39P or 39Q may also be used for a laboratory test for alcohol (in addition to a test for any drug) in connection with an alleged offence under section 39J, 39K or 39L.

Evidence of the concentration of a drug, or the concentration of a drug and the proportion of alcohol, in a specimen of blood or urine taken under section 39P or 39Q may be given by the production of a document purporting to be a certificate under section 25 of the Evidence Ordinance (Cap. 8) as to the concentration of the drug, or the concentration of the drug and the proportion of alcohol, in the specimen of blood or urine identified in the certificate.

Evidence of the presence of a drug, or the presence of a drug and the proportion of alcohol, in a specimen of blood or urine taken under section 39P or 39Q may be given by the production of a document purporting to be a certificate under section 25 of the Evidence Ordinance (Cap. 8) as to the presence of the drug, or the presence of the drug and the proportion of alcohol, in the specimen of blood or urine identified in the certificate.

Evidence of the concentration of a drug, or the concentration of a drug and the proportion of alcohol, in a specimen of blood or urine provided by the accused person is evidence that the concentration of the drug, or the concentration of the drug and the proportion of alcohol, in the blood or urine of the accused person at the time of the alleged offence was not less than that in the specimen.

Evidence of the presence of a drug, or the presence of a drug and the proportion of alcohol, in a specimen of blood or urine provided by the accused person is evidence of the presence of the drug, or the presence of the drug and the proportion of alcohol, in the blood or urine of the accused person at the time of the alleged offence.

subsection.leadIn: If at the time a specimen of blood or urine was provided by an accused person under section 39P, he or she asked to be provided with a part of the specimen of blood or urine or a part of each specimen (if both blood and urine specimens are provided by the accused person), evidence of the concentration of or the presence of a drug, or the concentration of or the presence of a drug and the proportion of alcohol, found in the specimen is not admissible on behalf of the prosecution unless—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the specimen in which the drug or the drug and alcohol was found is one of 2 parts into which the specimen provided by the accused person was divided at the time it was provided; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the other part was supplied to the accused person.

subsection.leadIn: If an accused person from whom a specimen of blood was taken under section 39Q, at the time he or she consented to its analysis, asked to be provided with a part of that specimen, evidence of the concentration of or the presence of a drug, or the concentration of or the presence of a drug and the proportion of alcohol, found in the specimen is not admissible on behalf of the prosecution unless—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the specimen in which the drug or the drug and alcohol was found is one of 2 parts into which the specimen taken from the accused person was divided at the time it was taken; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the other part was supplied to the accused person.

section.name: s39S
section.heading: Failure to provide specimen of blood or urine

subsection.leadIn: A person who, without reasonable excuse, fails to provide a specimen of blood or urine when required to do so under section 39P or fails to give consent under section 39Q(4)(b) commits an offence and is liable—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: on conviction on indictment, to a fine at level 4 and to imprisonment for 3 years; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: on summary conviction—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: on a first offence under this subsection, to a fine at level 3 and to imprisonment for 6 months;

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: subsequent to a conviction on indictment under this subsection, to a fine at level 4 and to imprisonment for 12 months;

subparagraph.name: iii
subparagraph.content: subsequent to a summary conviction under this subsection, to a fine at level 4 and to imprisonment for 12 months; or

subparagraph.name: iv
subparagraph.content: subsequent to a conviction under section 39J, 39K, 39L or 39O(1), to a fine at level 4 and to imprisonment for 12 months.

subsection.leadIn: Without limiting subsection (1), a person fails to provide a specimen of blood or urine for analysis or laboratory test unless the specimen—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: is sufficient to enable the analysis or laboratory test to be carried out; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: is provided in a way to enable the objective of the analysis or laboratory test to be satisfactorily achieved.

subsection.content: If a court or magistrate convicts a person of an offence under subsection (1), the court or magistrate must order that the person be disqualified in accordance with subsection (4) or (5) unless the court or magistrate for special reasons orders that the person be disqualified for a shorter period or that the person not be disqualified.

subsection.leadIn: Subject to subsection (5), the period for which the person is to be disqualified—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: for a first conviction, is a period of not less than 5 years; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: for a subsequent conviction, is a period of not less than 10 years.

subsection.leadIn: If the court or magistrate has ordered the person to attend and complete a driving improvement course under section 72A(1A), the person is to be disqualified—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: for a first conviction, for a period of not less than 5 years, or until the person has attended and completed the course at his or her own cost, whichever is the later; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: for a subsequent conviction, for a period of not less than 10 years, or until the person has attended and completed the course at his or her own cost, whichever is the later.

subsection.leadIn: For the purposes of subsection (3), a person to whom subsection (5) applies is disqualified for a shorter period if the period for which he or she is disqualified—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: for a first conviction, is a period of less than 5 years, or until he or she has attended and completed the driving improvement course at his or her own cost, whichever is the later; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: for a subsequent conviction, is a period of less than 10 years, or until he or she has attended and completed the driving improvement course at his or her own cost, whichever is the later.

subsection.content: The court or magistrate may deal with the offence as a first offence, or the conviction of an offence as a first conviction, if, as at the date on which the offence was committed, at least 5 years have passed since the person’s last conviction under subsection (1) or section 39J, 39K, 39L or 39O(1).

subsection.leadIn: In this section—
subsection.def: first conviction (首次定罪) means a conviction on a first offence under subsection (1) (whether a conviction on indictment or a summary conviction);

def.name: SubsequentConviction
def.leadIn: subsequent conviction (再次定罪) means—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a conviction subsequent to a first conviction; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a conviction referred to in subsection (1)(b)(ii), (iii) or (iv).

section.name: s39T
section.heading: Tests to be included in Impairment Test, approval of instruments for preliminary drug tests, etc.

subsection.content: The Commissioner of Police may, by notice published in the Gazette, specify the tests to be carried out for the purpose of assisting a police officer to form an opinion as to whether or not a person’s ability to drive properly is impaired by the consumption or use of drugs.
The Commissioner of Police may, by notice published in the Gazette, approve types of instruments as approved instruments for carrying out a Rapid Oral Fluid Test.
The Commissioner of Police may authorize in writing members of the police force as authorized police officers to carry out preliminary drug tests.

Only an instrument approved under subsection (2) may be used for carrying out a Rapid Oral Fluid Test, and more than one such instrument may be used when carrying out a Rapid Oral Fluid Test on a person.
Only an authorized police officer may carry out a preliminary drug test.

subsection.leadIn: A police officer may require a person to surrender his or her licence for driving to the Commissioner of Police for 24 hours if—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the police officer has reasonable cause to suspect that the person has committed a relevant offence;

paragraph.name: b
c
paragraph.content: the result of an Impairment Test carried out under section 39M indicates, in the opinion of the police officer who carried out the test, that his or her ability to drive properly is for the time being impaired; or

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: the result of a Rapid Oral Fluid Test carried out under section 39M or 39N indicates the presence of any concentration of a specified illicit drug in his or her oral fluid.

subsection.content: In each case referred to in subsection (1), the period of 24 hours begins at the time the requirement is made.

subsection.name: 2A
subsection.content: A person who is required under subsection (1) to surrender his or her licence for driving is to be regarded as having complied with the requirement if the person produces his or her electronic driving licence to the police officer. (Added 26 of 2025 s. 4)

subsection.leadIn: A person who, without reasonable excuse, fails to surrender his or her licence for driving when required to do so by a police officer commits an offence and is liable on—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a first conviction to a fine at level 1; and (Amended E.R. 6 of 2022)

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a subsequent conviction to a fine at level 1.

subsection.content: A person who has been required to surrender, or has surrendered, a licence for driving under subsection (1), must not drive or attempt to drive, or be in charge of, a motor vehicle of any class on any road during the 24-hour period for which the licence for driving was required to be surrendered, whether or not he or she holds any other licence for driving referred to in subsection (7).
A person who contravenes subsection (4) commits an offence and is liable to a fine at level 3 and to imprisonment for 12 months.

subsection.leadIn: If a court or magistrate convicts a person of an offence under subsection (5), the court or magistrate must order that the person be disqualified—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: for a first conviction, for a period of not less than 12 months; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: for a subsequent conviction under that subsection, for a period of not less than 3 years,

subsection.continued: unless the court or magistrate for special reasons orders that the person be disqualified for a shorter period or that the person not be disqualified.

subsection.leadIn: In this section—

def.name: LicenceForDriving
def.leadIn: licence for driving (車牌) means—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a driving licence;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: an international driving permit;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: a domestic driving licence; or

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: a domestic driving permit;

def.name: RelevantOffence
def.leadIn: relevant offence (相關罪行) means—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: an offence under section 39B(6);

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: an offence under section 39C(15) (other than a failure to give consent under section 39C(11D)(b));

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: an offence under section 39O(1); or

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: an offence under section 39S(1) (other than a failure to give consent under section 39Q(4)(b)).

subsection.content: Subject to subsections (2), (5) and (5A), the maximum speed at which a vehicle may be driven on any road shall be 50 km an hour. (Amended 6 of 2012 s. 5)

subsection.leadIn: The Commissioner may by notice in the Gazette—

paragraph.name: a
b
paragraph.content: declare that any road specified in the notice is liable to be subject at different times to different speed limits;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: in respect of any portion of a road, exempt vehicles of the North-west Railway from the speed limit prescribed under subsection (1) and prescribe a different speed limit at which a vehicle of the North-west Railway may be driven on that portion of the road and different limits may be prescribed in respect of different portions of a road. (Added 46 of 1987 s. 5)

subsection.content: Where the speed limit on any road is varied under subsection (2)(a) the Commissioner shall cause traffic signs to be so erected, replaced, removed or altered as to ensure that adequate guidance is given to drivers of motor vehicles as to what speed limit is currently to be observed on that road.

subsection.leadIn: Where a notice is published under subsection (2)(b) declaring any road to be subject at different times to different speed limits—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the different speed limits which may be brought into effect on the road shall be specified in the notice; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: any change in the speed limit in accordance with the notice may be put into effect from time to time by the Commissioner causing traffic signs to be so erected, replaced, removed or altered as to ensure that adequate guidance is given to drivers of motor vehicles as to what speed limit is currently to be observed on that road.

subsection.leadIn: Where a variation in the speed limit is in effect under this section and permits a vehicle to travel on any road in excess of 70 km an hour, the maximum speed at which a—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: medium goods vehicle;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: heavy goods vehicle;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: bus;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: motor cycle, motor tricycle, private car or light goods vehicle driven by a person who is authorized to drive it by a probationary driving licence, (Replaced 23 of 2008 s. 12)

subsection.continued: shall travel on such road shall be 70 km an hour. (Amended 49 of 2000 s. 2)

subsection.name: 5A
subsection.content: If a variation in the speed limit is in effect under this section and permits a vehicle to travel on any road at a speed in excess of 80 km an hour, the maximum speed at which a public light bus may travel on that road is 80 km an hour. (Added 6 of 2012 s. 5)

Where the Commissioner prescribes a different speed limit for vehicles of the North-west Railway in respect of a portion of road under subsection (2)(c), the Commissioner may cause traffic signs to be so erected, replaced, removed or altered as to give adequate guidance or notice to drivers of vehicles of the North-west Railway of the application of that speed limit to that portion of road. (Added 46 of 1987 s. 5)

section.name: s41
section.heading: Driving in excess of speed limit

subsection.leadIn: A person who drives a vehicle on a road at a speed exceeding— (Amended 80 of 1988 s. 9)

paragraph.name: a
b
paragraph.content: 70 km an hour as provided for in section 40(5); or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: 80 km an hour as provided for in section 40(5A), (Added 6 of 2012 s. 6)

subsection.continued: commits an offence and is liable to a fine at level 2. (Amended 6 of 2012 s. 6; E.R. 2 of 2021)

subsection.leadIn: If—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a court or magistrate convicts a person of an offence under subsection (1); and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: it is proved or admitted that, at the time of the offence, the person was driving the vehicle at a speed exceeding the relevant speed limit as described in that subsection by more than 45 km an hour,

subsection.continued: the court or magistrate shall order that the person be disqualified in accordance with subsection (4) unless the court or magistrate for special reasons orders that he be disqualified for a shorter period or that he not be disqualified. (Added 50 of 2000 s. 3. Amended 23 of 2008 s. 13)

subsection.leadIn: The person is to be disqualified—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: subject to paragraph (b), for a period of not less than 6 months; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: if the court or magistrate has ordered the person to attend and complete a driving improvement course under section 72A(1A), for a period of not less than 6 months, or until the person has attended and completed the course at his own cost, whichever is the later. (Added 23 of 2008 s. 13)

subsection.content: For the purposes of subsection (3), a person to whom subsection (4)(b) applies is disqualified for a shorter period if he is disqualified for a period of less than 6 months, or until the person has attended and completed the driving improvement course at his own cost, whichever is the later. (Added 23 of 2008 s. 13)

Except as otherwise provided by this Ordinance, no person shall drive a motor vehicle on a road unless he is the holder of a driving licence in respect of a vehicle of the class of vehicle which he is driving.

subsection.leadIn: Except as otherwise provided by this Ordinance, a person must not drive a motor vehicle on a road unless at the time of driving, the person— (Amended 26 of 2025 s. 5)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: carries his or her driving licence or a document issued by the Commissioner indicating that the person has applied for the renewal or a duplicate of his or her driving licence; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: carries, or can readily avail himself or herself of, an electronic device on which his or her electronic driving licence can be readily displayed. (Amended 26 of 2025 s. 5)

content.leadIn: Except as otherwise provided by this Ordinance, no person shall suffer or permit a motor vehicle to be driven by a person who is not the holder of a driving licence of the class to which such vehicle belongs:
content.proviso: Provided that in any proceedings under this subsection it shall not be necessary to allege or to prove that the person charged knew that the driver was not the holder of a driving licence and it shall be no defence to prove that the person charged did not know that the driver was not the holder of a driving licence. (Amended 66 of 1987 s. 2)

subsection.content: Any person who contravenes subsection (1) or (3) commits an offence and is liable, in the case of a first conviction to a fine at level 2 and to imprisonment for 3 months, and in the case of a second or subsequent conviction or of a conviction subsequent to a conviction under section 5(4) or (5) of the repealed Ordinance to a fine at level 3 and to imprisonment for 6 months. (Amended E.R. 2 of 2021)

Any person who without lawful authority or reasonable excuse contravenes subsection (2) commits an offence and is liable, in the case of a first conviction to a fine at level 1, and in the case of a second or subsequent conviction or of a conviction subsequent to a conviction under section 5(4A) of the repealed Ordinance to a fine at level 1. (Amended E.R. 6 of 2022)

section.name: s43
section.heading: Enforcement powers of a police officer or the Commissioner

subsection.leadIn: A police officer or the Commissioner may require the production for examination of the driving licence of any person—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: who is driving a motor vehicle on a road; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: whom he reasonably suspects to have been the driver of a motor vehicle involved in an accident on a road; or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: whom he reasonably suspects to have committed an offence under this Ordinance or to have contravened the Fixed Penalty (Traffic Contraventions) Ordinance (Cap. 237); or

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: whom he has reasonable cause to believe has knowingly made a false statement for the purposes of obtaining the grant of the driving licence.

subsection.content: If any condition of a driving licence requires the holder of that licence while driving or learning to drive a motor vehicle to be under the supervision of or to be accompanied by the holder of a driving licence, a police officer or the Commissioner may in the case of a motor vehicle being driven by the holder of such a driving licence as is first mentioned also require any accompanying person to produce his driving licence for examination.

subsection.leadIn: Any person who, upon being required to produce his or her driving licence under subsection (1)(a), fails to produce any of the following documents— (Amended 26 of 2025 s. 6)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the person’s driving licence; (Replaced 26 of 2025 s. 6)

paragraph.name: ab
paragraph.content: the person’s electronic driving licence; (Added 26 of 2025 s. 6)

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a document issued by the Commissioner indicating that the person has applied for the renewal or a duplicate of his or her driving licence,

subsection.continued: commits an offence and is liable to a fine at level 1 and to imprisonment for 3 months. (Amended E.R. 2 of 2021)

subsection.content: Any person who, upon being required to produce his or her driving licence under subsection (1), fails to produce any of the documents specified in subsection (4A) and who further fails to produce any of those documents, in person, within 72 hours of such requirement being made, to a police officer at such police station or other official address as is specified at the time commits an offence and is liable to a fine at level 1 and to imprisonment for 3 months. (Amended 66 of 1984 s. 5; E.R. 2 of 2021)

subsection.name: 4A
subsection.leadIn: The documents specified for subsection (4) are—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the person’s driving licence;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the person’s electronic driving licence; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: a document issued by the Commissioner indicating that the person has applied for the renewal or a duplicate of his or her driving licence. (Added 26 of 2025 s. 6)

subsection.name: 4B
subsection.content: A person who is required under subsection (2) to produce his or her driving licence is to be regarded as having complied with the requirement if the person produces his or her electronic driving licence to the police officer or the Commissioner (as may be applicable). (Added 26 of 2025 s. 6)
This section (except subsections (3)(ab), (4A)(b) and (4B)) applies to a domestic driving permit, domestic driving licence and international driving permit as it applies to a driving licence.

section.name: s44
section.heading: Offence of obtaining licence, or driving, while disqualified

subsection.leadIn: A person disqualified from holding or obtaining a driving licence who—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: obtains a driving licence while he is disqualified; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: while he is disqualified drives on a road a motor vehicle or, if the disqualification is limited to the driving of a motor vehicle of a particular class, a motor vehicle of that class,

subsection.continued: commits an offence and is liable to a fine at level 3 and to imprisonment for 12 months. (Amended E.R. 2 of 2021)

subsection.leadIn: If a court or magistrate convicts a person of an offence under subsection (1), the court or magistrate shall order that the person be disqualified—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: in the case of a first conviction, for a period of not less than 12 months; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: in the case of a second or subsequent conviction, or a conviction subsequent to a conviction under section 25 of the repealed Ordinance, for a period of not less than 3 years,

subsection.continued: unless the court or magistrate for special reasons orders that the person be disqualified for a shorter period or that the person not be disqualified. (Replaced 23 of 2008 s. 14)

subsection.content: The period of any disqualification under subsection (2) shall be in addition to any other period of disqualification ordered under any other provision of this Ordinance.

The provisions of subsection (1) shall apply notwithstanding that the person disqualified holds a valid international driving permit, driving licence issued in a place outside Hong Kong for use in that place, government driving permit or military driving permit. (Amended 23 of 1998 s. 2)

A person who uses or rides a bicycle, tricycle or multi-cycle on a road recklessly commits an offence and is liable in the case of a first conviction to a fine at level 1 and in the case of a second or subsequent conviction to a fine at level 1 and to imprisonment for 3 months. (Amended 89 of 1994 s. 17; E.R. 6 of 2022)
On the trial of any person for an offence under subsection (1) he may be acquitted of that offence and be found guilty of an offence under section 46.
A person who uses or rides a bicycle, tricycle or multi-cycle on a road carelessly commits an offence and is liable to a fine at level 1. (Amended E.R. 2 of 2021)

A person uses or rides carelessly within the meaning of this section if on a road he uses or rides a bicycle, tricycle or multi-cycle without due care and attention or without reasonable consideration for other persons using the road.

section.name: s47
section.heading: Cycling, etc. when under the influence of drink or drugs
section.content: A person who, when using or riding a bicycle, tricycle or multi-cycle, or when driving a rickshaw, on a road or in a public place, is unfit to ride or drive through drink or drugs commits an offence and is liable in the case of a first conviction to a fine at level 1, and in the case of a second or subsequent conviction or of a conviction subsequent to a conviction under section 13 of the repealed Ordinance to a fine at level 1 and to imprisonment for 3 months.

section.name: s48
section.heading: Offences by pedestrians
section.content: A pedestrian who in using any road, or a person who by driving a rickshaw on any road, negligently endangers his own safety or that of any other person commits an offence and is liable to a fine at level 1.

section.name: s49
section.heading: Tampering with motor vehicles
section.content: If a person otherwise than with lawful authority or reasonable excuse gets on to a vehicle or tampers with any part of the vehicle, he commits an offence and is liable to a fine at level 2 and to imprisonment for 12 months.

section.name: s50
section.heading: Interfering with traffic signs or road markings
section.leadIn: Any person who without the consent of the Commissioner, Commissioner of Police or Director of Highways— (Amended L.N. 127 of 1986)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: moves, damages or interferes in any way with any traffic sign or prescribed traffic sign; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: obscures, defaces, alters or obliterates any road marking or prescribed road marking,

section.continued: commits an offence and is liable to a fine at level 1 and to imprisonment for 3 months.

section.name: s51
section.heading: Prohibition of unauthorized signs or markings

subsection.leadIn: A person who other than—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: in accordance with a permit issued under this Ordinance; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: in order to comply with any enactment or the road users’ code or any code of practice under section 109, (Amended 66 of 1984 s. 6)

subsection.continued: places, causes or permits to be placed, in, on or near a road or on a building any traffic sign or road marking commits an offence and is liable to a fine at level 1 and to imprisonment for 3 months. (Amended E.R. 2 of 2021)

subsection.content: The Commissioner may by notice in writing require any person who has placed or caused to be placed any such road marking or traffic sign to remove the same, and, if such person fails to comply with such notice, the Commissioner may cause the road marking to be obliterated or removed, or the traffic sign to be removed, as the case may be, and thereupon the road marking or traffic sign and any part thereof and every attachment thereto shall be forfeited to the Government and the Commissioner may recover from such person as a civil debt the cost of the obliteration or removal of the road marking or of the traffic sign and also the cost of any reinstatement of the road necessitated by such obliteration or removal. (Amended 3 of 2002 s. 15)

part.name: P6
part.heading: Use, Sale and Hire of Vehicles

section.name: s52
section.heading: Restriction on the use of vehicles

subsection.leadIn: Subject to this Ordinance, no person shall—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: drive or use a vehicle of a class specified in Schedule 1, other than a rickshaw; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: suffer or permit such a vehicle to be driven or used,

subsection.continued: on a road unless the vehicle is registered and licensed in accordance with this Ordinance.

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: No person shall ride or otherwise use a multi-cycle except in a manner and on a road or in a place specified for the purposes of this subsection by the Commissioner.

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: Where the Commissioner specifies a road or place under paragraph (a), he may also specify 1 or more traffic signs or road markings which are to be used as regards that road or place.

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: Where the Commissioner exercises a power under paragraph (a) or (b), he shall as soon as may be cause to be published in the Gazette a notice giving particulars of anything specified in exercise of the power. (Added 89 of 1994 s. 20)

subsection.leadIn: No person shall—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: drive or use a rickshaw; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: suffer or permit a rickshaw to be driven or used,

subsection.continued: on a road unless the rickshaw is licensed in accordance with this Ordinance.

subsection.leadIn: No person shall—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: drive or use a motor vehicle; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: suffer or permit a motor vehicle to be driven or used,

subsection.continued: for the carriage of passengers for hire or reward unless— (Amended L.N. 100 of 1984)

paragraph.name: i
paragraph.content: the vehicle is licensed as a public bus, public light bus or taxi;

paragraph.name: ii
paragraph.content: the vehicle is licensed as a private bus and the passengers are students, teachers or employees of an educational institution, disabled persons, or persons employed to assist disabled persons; (Amended 50 of 1999 s. 10)

paragraph.name: iia
paragraph.leadIn: the vehicle is licensed as a private light bus and is used—

subparagraph.name: A
subparagraph.content: as a school private light bus; or

subparagraph.name: B
subparagraph.content: exclusively for the carriage of persons who are disabled persons and persons assisting them; or (Added 50 of 1999 s. 10)

paragraph.name: iii
paragraph.content: a hire car permit is in force in respect of the vehicle.

subsection.leadIn: No person shall—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: drive or use a public light bus, a private bus, a school private light bus or a public bus other than one operated under a franchise granted under the Public Bus Services Ordinance (Cap. 230); or (Amended 50 of 1999 s. 10)

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: suffer or permit such a vehicle to be driven or used,

subsection.continued: for the carriage of passengers unless a passenger service licence is in force in respect of the vehicle.

subsection.leadIn: No person shall solicit or attempt to solicit any person for hire or reward to travel in any vehicle which is licensed as—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a private car;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a private light bus;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: a private bus;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: a light goods vehicle;

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: a medium goods vehicle; or

paragraph.name: f
paragraph.content: a heavy goods vehicle.

subsection.content: No person shall permit or suffer a motor vehicle which is licensed as a private car, private light bus or private bus to stand or ply for hire or reward.

subsection.leadIn: Subject to this Ordinance, no person shall—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: drive or use a motor vehicle; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: suffer or permit a motor vehicle to be driven or used,

subsection.continued: for the carriage of goods (other than personal effects) for hire or reward unless—

paragraph.name: i
paragraph.content: the vehicle is licensed as a light goods vehicle, a medium goods vehicle or a heavy goods vehicle; or

paragraph.name: ii
paragraph.content: in the case of a vehicle licensed as a public bus, a private bus, a public light bus or a private light bus, the Commissioner has issued a permit for such carriage of goods by the vehicle.

subsection.leadIn: No person shall without the permission in writing of the Commissioner—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: drive or use; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: permit or suffer to be driven or used,

subsection.continued: a motor vehicle which is licensed as a private car for the carriage of goods the total weight of which exceeds 200 kg.

subsection.leadIn: No person shall—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: drive or use; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: permit or suffer to be driven or used,

subsection.continued: a motor vehicle in contravention of any conditions subject to which the vehicle licence was issued.

subsection.leadIn: Any person who contravenes—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: this section (other than subsection (2), (3), (5) or (6)) commits an offence and is liable in the case of a first conviction for that offence to a fine at level 2 and to imprisonment for 3 months, and in the case of a second or subsequent conviction for that offence to a fine at level 3 and to imprisonment for 6 months; (Amended E.R. 2 of 2021)

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: subsection (2) commits an offence and is liable in the case of a first conviction for that offence to a fine at level 1 and to imprisonment for 3 months, and in the case of a second or subsequent conviction for that offence to a fine at level 1 and to imprisonment for 6 months; (Amended E.R. 6 of 2022; 34 of 2023 s. 55)

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.leadIn: subsection (3), (5) or (6) commits an offence and is liable—

subparagraph.content: on a first conviction—to a fine at level 3 and to imprisonment for 6 months; and
on a subsequent conviction—to a fine at level 4 and to imprisonment for 12 months. (Added 34 of 2023 s. 55)

subsection.def: In this section advertising vehicle (廣告車輛) means a vehicle used or intended to be used predominantly for the displaying of advertising.

subsection.leadIn: No person shall—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: drive or use; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: permit or suffer to be driven or used,

subsection.continued: an advertising vehicle—

paragraph.name: i
paragraph.content: without a permit issued by the Commissioner allowing its use for that purpose; or

paragraph.name: ii
paragraph.content: in contravention of any of the terms or conditions attached to a permit referred to in paragraph (i).

subsection.content: Subject to this section, the Commissioner may, on application by the owner of a vehicle and on payment of the prescribed fee, issue a permit for the use of the vehicle as an advertising vehicle.
The Commissioner shall not issue a permit under this section unless he is satisfied that the advertising to be displayed will be displayed for a non-commercial purpose.
The Commissioner may attach such conditions to a permit issued under this section as he considers necessary, including the period for which the permit will be effective.

A person who contravenes subsection (2) commits an offence and is liable in the case of a first conviction to a fine at level 2 and to imprisonment for 3 months, and in the case of a second or subsequent conviction to a fine at level 3 and to imprisonment for 6 months. (Amended E.R. 2 of 2021)

section.name: s53
section.heading: Prohibition of sale, hire etc. of vehicles not complying with regulations

subsection.leadIn: Subject to subsection (3), no person shall—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: sell, supply or hire;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: offer to sell, supply or hire; or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: cause or permit to be sold, supplied or hired, or offered for sale, supply or hire,

subsection.continued: a motor vehicle or trailer for delivery in such a condition—

paragraph.name: i
paragraph.content: that the use thereof on a road would contravene any provision of this Ordinance with respect to the construction or weight of the vehicle or its equipment, or with respect to the maintenance of the vehicle or its equipment;

paragraph.name: ii
paragraph.content: that danger is or is likely to be caused by it to any person; or

paragraph.name: iii
paragraph.content: as respects lighting equipment or reflectors or the maintenance thereof, that it is not capable of being used on a road during the hours of darkness without contravening any provision of this Ordinance as to obligatory lamps or reflectors.

subsection.content: Subject to subsection (3), no person shall alter or cause or permit to be altered a motor vehicle or trailer so as to render its condition such that the use thereof on a road would contravene any provision of this Ordinance as to the construction, weight, equipment, brakes, steering gear or tyres thereof.

subsection.leadIn: Any person who contravenes subsection (1) or (2) commits an offence and is liable to a fine at level 4: (Amended E.R. 2 of 2021)
